questions.prompt: Do people usually FROLIC at funerals?
Is there likely to be CONGESTION on a desert island?
Does a person VIOLATE the law when he steals something?
Would an expert have problems with something at an INTERMEDIATE level of difficulty?
Can a dog give you a warm RECEPTION?
Is margarine used as a SUBSTITUTE for butter?
Is New York City in the VICINITY of Los Angeles?
If a television program ended in the middle of a sentence, would its ending be ABRUPT?
If a person's anger is EVIDENT, is he hiding it very well?
If someone tried to BAN baseball in the United States, would he be successful?
Would a lightning flash ENDURE for hours?
Is a snail a FRISKY animal?
Do you PAMPER a small child by spanking him?
The baby was laughing and splashing and FROLICKING in the bathtub.
There was a lot of CONGESTION about what exactly we were supposed to do.
The prisoner claimed that his rights were VIOLATED because he wasn't allowed to speak to a lawyer.
Thomas had to take INTERMEDIATE-level Spanish over again.
Magicians practice for a long time to become skillful in their RECEPTIONS.
She tried to STEER the conversation toward a more interesting subject, but everyone else wanted to talk about sports.
The store SUBSTITUTED a cheaper brand of paper for the one we ordered.
We couldn't see him, but we knew he was somewhere in the VICINITY.
She ABRUPTLY decided she didn't like the dance, and left immediately.
EVIDENTLY we didn't make the team; our names aren't on the list.
As punishment, their parents placed a BAN on watching television.
She was able to ENDURE the pain by taking aspirin three times a day.
We refused to become involved in their silly FEUD.
The children were having a FRISKY game of tag.
He said that even though he was ill he didn't want to be PAMPERED.

FROLIC.deftext:
to make merry, play happily, romp 
To FROLIC is to play in a lighthearted, carefree way. The word is used especially about children or about people acting like children. 
"I love to see children FROLIC at the beach." 
"She FROLICKED about the yard, singing happily." 
FROLIC can also be used as a noun. 
"After their FROLIC in the snow they came inside, cold but happy." 
Usage: The past tense of FROLIC is spelled FROLICKED.

CONGESTION.deftext:
overcrowding, overfullness 
To CONGEST means to _overfill_ or _overcrowd_. 
"The subway trains are always CONGESTED at five o'clock in the evening." 
CONGESTION is the state of being overcrowded or too full. "Traffic CONGESTION" is when there are so many cars on a street that traffic becomes blocked. "Lung CONGESTION" is when the lungs become so full of fluid that it is difficult to breathe. 
"So many people crowded onto the subway platform that the CONGESTION was terrible." 
"CONGESTION became so bad in the city that many people moved to the suburbs." 
Other forms of the word: CONGEST, v.

VIOLATE.deftext:
to break, interfere with, treat badly 
To VIOLATE a law or rule is to break it, to fail to keep it. 
"If you VIOLATE this law, you will be sent to jail." 
"He VIOLATED our order to stay inside." 
In another sense, VIOLATE means "to treat in an improper manner." The word is used especially about non-physical things like rights or dignity. 
"His orders VIOLATE our basic human rights." 
"Bill didn't like anyone to VIOLATE his privacy." 
Other forms of the word: VIOLATION, n.

INTERMEDIATE.deftext:
in the middle, in between 
See _inter-_ under Prefixes and _-ate2_ under Suffixes. The _medi_ part of INTERMEDIATE comes from the Latin word for _middle_, which is also the source of the word _medium_. Something that is INTERMEDIATE comes in the middle; it is, for example, between two stages, times, or extremes. 
"He was too good for the beginners' group, and not good enough for the advanced group, so they put him in the INTERMEDIATE group." 
"There are several INTERMEDIATE steps between starting the machine and getting the final product."

RECEPTION.deftext:
a welcome, greeting 
RECEPTION is the act of receiving. It is often used about the receiving of guests. 
"I got a cool RECEPTION from the host when I arrived two hours late." 
A wedding RECEPTION is the formal receiving of guests after a wedding. RECEPTION is used for other kinds of receiving as well, like the receiving of radio or television signals. 
"We had very poor RECEPTION on our TV until we bought an antenna." On the Pretest, many people confuse RECEPTION with _farewell_, which is an exact opposite. 
Other forms of the word: RECEPTIVE, adj.

STEER.deftext:
to guide, lead, direct the course of 
To STEER something is to guide it in a particular direction. The word can be used about physical objects like cars and boats and about conversations, interests, and the like. 
"Jane STEERED the canoe with her paddle." 
"He STEERED us quickly through the crowded station." 
"You STEER a car by turning the STEERING wheel." 
"We tried to STEER him toward college, but he wanted to work after high school."

SUBSTITUTE.deftext:
to put in place of, take the place of, exchange 
SUBSTITUTE is both a verb and a noun. To SUBSTITUTE something is to put or use it in place of something else. 
"He SUBSTITUTED the fake painting for the real one." 
"You may SUBSTITUTE margarine for butter when you make this cake." 
When something SUBSTITUTES for something else, it takes the place of it. 
"For a blind person, the other senses have to SUBSTITUTE for the sense of sight." 
A SUBSTITUTE is something that takes the place of something else. 
"The coach sent Bill in as a SUBSTITUTE for the center." 
Other forms of the word: SUBSTITUTION, n.

VICINITY.deftext:
neighborhood, surrounding area 
The area surrounding a place is called the VICINITY. "In the VICINITY of the school" means "near the school" or "in the neighborhood of the school." 
"She lives in the VICINITY of the hospital. Her apartment is just across the street." 
"There are several grocery stores in the VICINITY." 
"The robber was seen leaving the VICINITY of the bank at two o'clock."

ABRUPT.deftext:
sudden, unexpected; curt, blunt 
Something that is ABRUPT happens without warning. It occurs so suddenly that it is almost unpleasant. 
"His departure was ABRUPT, to say the least. One minute he was talking to me, the next minute he was gone." 
ABRUPT is often used about people and their behavior. A person who is ABRUPT is brief almost to the point of rudeness in the way he acts or speaks. 
"Mr. Ames has a rather ABRUPT manner that makes people feel he is eager to get rid of them."

EVIDENT.deftext:
clear, apparent, obvious, plain 
See _-ant_ under Suffixes. EVIDENT comes from the Latin root _vid_, which means to _see_. _Vid_ is also the source of the words _video_ and _vision_. Something that is EVIDENT is easily seen; it is plain and clear. It can be clear either to the eye or to the mind. 
"Her anger was EVIDENT from the way she went around slamming doors." 
"It became EVIDENT that our team just wasn't good enough to win." 
"The man EVIDENTLY was wealthy; he lived in a mansion." 
Other forms of the word: EVIDENCE, n.

BAN.deftext:
to forbid 
BAN means to _forbid_, "to give an order that something must not be done." 
"Cigarette smoking is BANNED in many restaurants." 
"Jim's mother BANNED all yelling in the house." 
BAN is also a noun, and means "an order forbidding something," a _prohibition_. 
"The government put a BAN on buying or selling gold." 
"There was a BAN on driving during the emergency."

ENDURE.deftext:
to put up with, bear; to last, continue 
ENDURE is related to the word _durable_. Both come from a Latin word that means _lasting_. ENDURE has two related meanings. The first is to _put up with_, especially with patience and for a long time. 
"I can't ENDURE listening to his complaints again." 
"Since you can't change the weather, you'll just have to ENDURE it." 
"That tree has ENDURED wind and rain and snow, and still it has survived." 
The second meaning is "to continue to exist" for a long time, to _last_. 
"His desire to learn ENDURED throughout his life." 
"The belief that the Earth was the center of the universe ENDURED for centuries." 
Other forms of the word: ENDURANCE, n.

FEUD.deftext:
a long, bitter quarrel 
Note the pronunciation. A FEUD is a quarrel that goes on over a long period of time. It is always bitter and sometimes violent. 
"They had forgotten what started the FEUD, but they were still angry with each other twenty years later." 
"The FEUD between the two families was never really settled." 
FEUD can also be used as a verb. 
"The two neighbors FEUDED over the location of the fence." 
"He FEUDED with his brothers over his share of the inheritance."

FRISKY.deftext:
lively, playful, energetic 
One meaning of the verb to FRISK is "to move about playfully." 
"The puppies FRISKED about on the lawn." 
FRISKY means "given to FRISKING," _lively_, _playful_. See _-y_ under Suffixes. 
"They thought the pony was too FRISKY, so they bought a slower, quieter one instead." 
"The old man started to feel a bit FRISKY on the bright spring morning." 
FRISKY is often confused with _friendly_, perhaps because the two words look alike. A pet or person could be both FRISKY and _friendly_, but the two words do not have the same meaning. 
Other forms of the word: FRISK, v.

PAMPER.deftext:
to spoil, indulge, humor, coddle 
To PAMPER someone is to treat him or her with too much care and attention, to be excessively kind. The word almost always suggests that this is a bad thing, and that the person who is PAMPERED may become spoiled as a result. 
"They PAMPER their children. They let them stay up late and eat nothing but desserts." 
"She decided to PAMPER herself and stay in bed till noon." 
"She was PAMPERED as a child, and now she can't do anything for herself."

questions.prompt: Do some people CRINGE at the sight of blood?
Do people try to avoid PLAGUES?
Would SACRED things usually be thrown away?
Would a slap in the face PROVOKE most people?
Would a person usually SHUDDER with joy?
Is a gallon of milk EXHAUSTED when most of it is gone?
Do skaters sometimes SPRAWL when they lose their balance?
Does LEAN meat have a lot of fat on it?
Would a person who is BEFUDDLED give clear directions?
Would most people CONSENT to being given a raise?
Does a rock DESCEND when you drop it?
Do most students find homework ENCHANTING?
Are palm trees the DOMINANT form of life at the North Pole?
The dog CRINGED when he saw that his master was angry with him.
She was PLAGUED by doubts about her ability to sing in public.
In ancient times they considered this tree to be SACRED and offered sacrifices to it.
He had his license PROVOKED for three years.
They SALVAGED what they could from the office after it had been robbed.
It makes me SHUDDER to think of how close we all came to drowning.
Spring house cleaning left us all EXHAUSTED.
He was a rather CONTAGIOUS person, always getting angry at people for no reason.
He SPRAWLED as quickly as he could from one side of the room to the other.
He kept himself LEAN by not overeating.
Sally was delighted when the most popular girl in the class BEFUDDLED her.
The farmer said he would never CONSENT to sell his land.
The skier DESCENDED quickly to the bottom of the mountain.
He wrote ENCHANTING stories which little children loved to read.
Plans for escaping DOMINATED the thoughts of the prisoners.

CRINGE.deftext:
to shrink back, huddle, crouch down 
To CRINGE is to draw back from something, to huddle or crouch down in fear. 
"The shy child CRINGED at the sight of the stranger." 
"The thief CRINGED fearfully as the huge attack dog lunged at his neck." 
CRINGE sometimes suggests a total lack of self-respect. 
"The beggar CRINGED as he saw the powerful nobleman approach."

PLAGUE.deftext:
to torment, annoy, trouble, afflict 
Note the pronunciation. A PLAGUE is some kind of evil that causes widespread harm, especially a disease that spreads rapidly and causes fever and death. 
"Millions died when the PLAGUE swept across Europe in the Middle Ages." 
"The rising number of robberies is a PLAGUE upon the nation." 
As a verb, PLAGUE means to _trouble_ or _torment_ as if with a PLAGUE. 
"Bad luck seemed to PLAGUE him throughout life." 
"The project was PLAGUED with delays and problems." 
"Poor health PLAGUED her as she tried to study for her exams."

SACRED.deftext:
holy, divine 
Something that is SACRED is dedicated or set apart for some reason. 
"This field is SACRED to the memory of our soldiers who have fallen in battle." 
SACRED is usually used about things that are set apart for religious purposes; in this sense it means just about the same as _holy_. 
"These SACRED books may be opened only by the high priest." 
"I made a SACRED promise. It would be a sin to break it." 
Usage: SACRED is sometimes followed by _to_.

PROVOKE.deftext:
to stir up, call forth; to make angry 
See _pro-_ under Prefixes. The _voke_ part of the word means _call_. To PROVOKE is to call forth or stir up. 
"His jokes managed to PROVOKE a smile." 
"Her suggestion PROVOKED a long debate." 
Very often PROVOKE means "to call forth _anger_." To PROVOKE someone is to make him upset or angry. 
"Don't PROVOKE the cat or it will scratch you." 
"His enemy's insults PROVOKED him into starting a fight." 
On the Pretest, many people choose _stop_ as the meaning of PROVOKE. The two words are actually just about opposites. The confusion may be due to the similarity between PROVOKE and _revoke_, which means to _cancel_. 
Other forms of the word: PROVOCATION, n. PROVOCATIVE, adj.

SALVAGE.deftext:
to save, rescue 
To SALVAGE something is to save it, especially from loss or ruin. The word was originally used in shipping, where people would be paid for saving, or SALVAGING, cargo from a shipwreck. Now the word is also used about saving from any kind of loss or wreckage. 
"We managed to SALVAGE most of our furniture from the fire." 
"All our records were ruined in the flood. Nothing could be SALVAGED." 
SALVAGE is also a noun. It is the act of saving: 
"The SALVAGE of the ship was a difficult operation." 
Or the things that have been saved: 
"They piled up the ship's SALVAGE on the beach."

SHUDDER.deftext:
to tremble, shake, shiver 
To SHUDDER is to tremble or shake. When people SHUDDER, it is usually from fear or disgust. 
"She SHUDDERED when she heard the strange noises outside the room." 
"They SHUDDERED with horror at the sight of the dead bodies." 
Physical objects can also SHUDDER. 
"The whole house seemed to SHUDDER when the big trucks came roaring by." 
SHUDDER is also a noun, and means a _trembling_ or _shaking_. 
"A SHUDDER passed through him at the thought of the coming battle." 
Many people think SHUDDER means _moan_. These words might be used in the same situation—about a person who is afraid or in pain—but they do not have the same meaning.

EXHAUST.deftext:
to use up; to tire 
EXHAUST has two common meanings. The basic meaning of EXHAUST is "to use up so that there's nothing left." 
"Our supply of gasoline was almost EXHAUSTED, so we had to stop and buy some more." 
"The children's shouting finally EXHAUSTED her patience, and she told them to be quiet." 
When used about people, EXHAUST suggests that their strength or energy is all used up, so the word means to _tire_ or _wear out_. 
"The long drive totally EXHAUSTED him." 
"Even when she's EXHAUSTED she seems to find the strength to stay up and watch the late show." 
Other forms of the word: EXHAUSTION, n.

CONTAGIOUS.deftext:
catching 
CONTAGIOUS is primarily used about diseases, and means "spreading by contact." Scarlet fever is a CONTAGIOUS disease; you can come down with it by touching a person who has it. Diabetes is not a CONTAGIOUS disease; it is not spread by contact. 
"We stayed away from Jimmy when he had the chicken pox, because we were afraid the disease might be CONTAGIOUS." 
Other forms of the word: CONTAGION, n.

SPRAWL.deftext:
to spread out 
The verb to SPRAWL means "to spread out loosely, with arms and legs flung apart." 
"He was SPRAWLED on the bed"—that is, he was lying down with his arms and legs carelessly spread out. 
"The boy SPRAWLED on the sofa, with one leg dangling over its arm." 
SPRAWL can also be used about anything that is spread out in a loose or irregular way. 
"As more and more people came to the campground, tents SPRAWLED all over the place." 
SPRAWL is also a noun; a SPRAWL is the position you take when you SPRAWL. 
"She tripped and fell in a SPRAWL." 
Many people choose _crawl_ as the meaning of SPRAWL, probably because they sound alike, and both can take place on the floor. But _crawling_ is a way of moving, while SPRAWLING is a way of falling or lying.

LEAN.deftext:
thin, lacking fat; scarce, scanty 
When used about people or animals, LEAN means _thin_, "without much fat." 
"She eats very little so that she can have a LEAN figure." 
"He buys LEAN meat, because he believes that eating a lot of fat is bad for you." 
When used about other things, LEAN means "lacking in fullness or quantity," _unproductive_, _scarce_. 
"It was a LEAN harvest this year. We only got half as much corn as we expected." 
"There will be LEAN years ahead unless we all work harder." 
LEAN is confused by some people with _healthy_. A LEAN person might also be _healthy_, but the two words do not have the same meaning.

BEFUDDLE.deftext:
to confuse, puzzle, muddle 
To BEFUDDLE someone is to confuse him so that he can't understand what is going on. 
"He BEFUDDLED his son by giving him several orders one right after the other." 
"She was in a BEFUDDLED state for several hours after the operation; finally the drug wore off and her mind cleared." 
"Sally was completely BEFUDDLED by the strong opposition to her reasonable suggestion." 
"Liquor is known to BEFUDDLE people. They can't walk or think straight." 
_Amuse_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, perhaps because BEFUDDLE is a funny sounding word.

CONSENT.deftext:
to agree, give permission 
CONSENT means "to give permission or approval." The word suggests going along with a request or an idea; it does not necessarily suggest enthusiastic support for it. 
"The teacher CONSENTED to the suggestion that she delay the test." 
"He would not CONSENT to let them go out alone after dark." 
"I wanted to go to the movies, but my parents would not CONSENT." 
CONSENT is also a noun. 
"The committee gave their CONSENT to the plan." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _decide_, probably because you must decide whether or not you want something to happen before you CONSENT to it. 
Usage: CONSENT is often followed by _to_.

DESCEND.deftext:
to go down, come down 
See _de-_ under Prefixes. To DESCEND is to go from a higher level to a lower one. The word can be used about real heights: 
"She DESCENDED the stairs very slowly." 
Or about things that are like heights: 
"The book started brilliantly, then DESCENDED into stupidity." 
Many people choose _go away_ as the meaning of DESCEND, but DESCEND always has the idea of going _down_. 
The opposite of DESCEND is _ascend_, to _go up_. 
"He _ascended_ the mountain in the morning and DESCENDED it in the afternoon." 
Other forms of the word: DESCENT, n.

ENCHANTING.deftext:
charming, delightful, fascinating, bewitching 
To ENCHANT is to lay under a magic spell, to _charm_: 
"the ENCHANTED castle"; "the ENCHANTED forest." ENCHANTING is the adjective from ENCHANT and means _charming_, "so pleasant and delightful that it seems like magic." 
"The music was ENCHANTING. It held us in its spell." 
"She had an ENCHANTING smile that made everyone fall in love with her." 
Many people choose _exciting_ as the meaning of ENCHANTING. ENCHANTING suggests pleasure and delight, however, not excitement. 
Other forms of the word: ENCHANT, v. ENCHANTMENT, n.

DOMINATE.deftext:
to rule, hold power over, control, overshadow 
See _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The _domin_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning _lord_ or _master_. To DOMINATE something is to have control over it, to be so powerful or so numerous that nothing or no one else has a chance. 
"He was such a great player that he DOMINATED tennis for many years." 
"That one huge tree DOMINATED the entire landscape." 
"Three automakers DOMINATE the entire industry." 
"He DOMINATED the conversation; no one else had a chance to speak." 
Someone or something that has this kind of control is DOMINANT. 
"The DOMINANT activity around here is farming." 
"When the senator died, his replacement became the DOMINANT figure in the party." 
Other forms of the word: DOMINANT, adj. DOMINATION, n.

questions.prompt: Could a ROSTER be put on a bulletin board?
Do parallel lines INTERSECT each other?
Is a burning log ENVELOPED in flames?
Does a person with FEEBLE eyesight need glasses?
Is New York City the SITE of the White House?
Do the police INQUIRE into crimes?
Would you trust a FOE with your money?
Can a toothache cause INTENSE pain?
Can you carry a JAVELIN in your hands?
Is a rat in a cage LIBERATED?
Can you PLEAD for something you are not supposed to have?
Could too much weight inside cause a bag to RUPTURE?
Does eating good food and exercising help to increase your VIGOR?
The club added his name to the ROSTER when he paid his dues.
They're building a motel close to the INTERSECTION of the two highways.
The scientist ENVELOPED a new method for making steel.
Tom's FEEBLE attempt at humor didn't make anyone laugh.
He climbed up the SITE of the house to the roof.
He INQUIRED if there were any seats left on the airplane.
Although they were FOES they respected each other.
Bill was worried for a while, but then he became INTENSE when they told him everything was all right.
The warrior pulled back on the bow and shot the JAYELIN into the air.
These vegetables are PERISHABLE; you must eat them soon or they will go bad.
The cruel king LIBERATED his nation with an iron hand.
We PLEADED with the teacher not to give us any homework.
Nothing anyone could say or do could mend the RUPTURE between them.
After years of treatment in the mental hospital he became SANITARY once again.
Bill VIGOROUSLY denied having taken the money.

ROSTER.deftext:
a list of names 
A ROSTER is a _list_, especially a list of persons (as in the army) and the turns of duty each one will take. 
"He studied the ROSTER to find out when he had to work that week." 
ROSTER can be used about any list of names. 
"We are proud to add his name to our membership ROSTER." 
"They accidentally left his name off the team ROSTER."

INTERSECT.deftext:
to cross, cut across 
See _inter-_ under Prefixes. The _sect_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning to _cut_. To _bisect_ something is to cut it in half. To _dissect_ something is to cut it apart. To INTERSECT something is to cut across it, to divide it by passing across it. 
"The river INTERSECTS the state." 
Two things INTERSECT when they cross at a point. 
"The two roads INTERSECTED just north of the city." 
An INTERSECTION is a place where two things, especially roads, meet and cross. 
"It was a dangerous INTERSECTION, with cars traveling quickly along both roads." 
Other forms of the word: INTERSECTION, n.

ENVELOP.deftext:
to surround, enclose 
To ENVELOP something is to surround it completely, usually with clothing or a non-solid material. 
"Thick smoke ENVELOPED the burning building, and we couldn't see a thing." 
"She was completely ENVELOPED in blankets to keep from catching cold." 
"Dark clouds ENVELOPED the tops of the mountains." 
An ENVELOPE is what you put a letter in to mail it. Its basic meaning is "something that ENVELOPS," a _wrapper_ or _container_. 
Other forms of the word: ENVELOPE, n.

FEEBLE.deftext:
weak, frail; dim 
FEEBLE means _very weak_, "lacking strength or energy." The word is usually used about people and their actions. 
"He became very FEEBLE in his old age and couldn't do anything for himself." 
"She made a FEEBLE attempt to smile." 
"His arguments were extremely FEEBLE. Anyone could have pointed out the errors in his reasoning." 
When used about things, FEEBLE means _dim_, _faint_. 
"The old record player could only produce a very FEEBLE sound."

SITE.deftext:
location, position 
The SITE of something is the exact place where it was, is, or will be located. 
"They visited the SITE of the Battle of Gettysburg." 
"No one was allowed near the construction SITE while the building was going up." 
"This will be the SITE of the new city hall." 
On the Pretest, a common choice as a synonym for SITE is _view_. This is the result of confusion between SITE and _sight_, which sound the same but have different meanings. The _sight_ of something is a _view_ of it; the SITE of something is where it is located.

INQUIRE.deftext:
to ask, ask about 
INQUIRE means to _ask_ or _ask about_, usually in a formal way about something specific. 
"I wanted to INQUIRE about the job that was advertised in the newspaper." 
"She INQUIRED about my health." 
When used with _into_, INQUIRE means "to make an investigation." 
"The man from the insurance company INQUIRED into the condition of the car before the accident." 
An INQUIRY is the act of INQUIRING. 
"When his polite INQUIRY brought no response, he demanded that his questions be answered." 
Other forms of the word: INQUIRY, n.

FOE.deftext:
an enemy, opponent, adversary 
FOE and _enemy_ have just about the same meaning. _Enemy_ is the more common word. FOE sometimes suggests a more actively dangerous person than _enemy_. 
"We met our FOE in a fierce battle and we were victorious." 
"Even his greatest FOES admitted he was a generous man." 
"She was a bitter FOE of injustice."

INTENSE.deftext:
extreme, high in degree 
INTENSE comes from a Latin word meaning _stretched out_, _strained_, also the source of the English words _tense_ and _tension_. INTENSE means "existing in an extreme or strained degree." The word can be used in many different ways. 
"The INTENSE light bothered his eyes." 
"There was an INTENSE hatred between the two men." 
"The cold was so INTENSE that we began to shiver." 
INTENSE is also used about people who are full of strong feelings. 
"Jim is a very INTENSE young man. He is always getting excited about something." 
Other forms of the word: INTENSIFY, v. INTENSITY, n.

JAVELIN.deftext:
a light spear 
A JAVELIN is a light spear; it was originally used in hunting and in war, but now it is thrown for distance in track and field meets. 
"He set a new world's record for throwing the JAVELIN." 
Many people confuse JAVELIN with _knife_, probably because both are weapons.

PERISH.deftext:
to die, be destroyed, pass away completely 
To PERISH is to come to an end, to be destroyed, often in a violent way. The word is usually used about living things. 
"Hundreds of small birds and animals PERISHED in the forest fire." 
"The entire group of mountain climbers PERISHED from the cold winds." 
"My cousin's herd of horses PERISHED during the hurricane." 
PERISHABLE is the adjective from PERISH and means _easily ruined_, _quick to decay_. Generally, this form of the word is used when talking about food. 
"Supermarkets must keep PERISHABLE items, such as milk and butter, in refrigerated cases." 
Other forms of the word: PERISHABLE, adj.

LIBERATE.deftext:
to free, set free 
See _-ate1_ under Suffixes. LIBERATE comes from the same Latin word as _liberal_ and _liberty_. All have to do with _freedom_. To LIBERATE someone is to _free_ him. 
"President Abraham Lincoln LIBERATED the slaves in the United States." 
"Winning this money will LIBERATE us from all our worries." 
Many people pick _rule_ as the meaning of LIBERATE. _Rule_ means just about the opposite of LIBERATE. 
Other forms of the word: LIBERATION, n.

PLEAD.deftext:
to beg, appeal, implore, claim 
The basic use of PLEAD is in law. To PLEAD in law is to make an answer to a legal charge: "to plead innocent," "to plead insanity." From this it has come to mean "to offer as an excuse." 
"When asked for an explanation of his behavior, he PLEADED ignorance." 
In a related sense PLEAD means "to argue strongly or ask earnestly," to _beg_. 
"He PLEADED for a little more time to finish the test." 
"Mary PLEADED with them to let her and her sister join the club." 
Other forms of the word: PLEA, n.

RUPTURE.deftext:
to burst, break 
To RUPTURE something is to burst it, to break it apart. 
"She RUPTURED a blood vessel and was rushed to the hospital." 
The word is often used about a break in the friendly relations between people or countries. 
"The president's angry speech RUPTURED the relations between the two countries." 
When something RUPTURES, it bursts. 
"The weight of the water caused the dam to RUPTURE." 
"Her appendix RUPTURED, so the doctor operated immediately." 
RUPTURE is also a noun, meaning a _breaking apart_ or _bursting_. 
"The bitter disagreement caused a RUPTURE between the brothers that lasted for years."

SANITARY.deftext:
healthful, clean 
SANITARY means "of or relating to health." The word is especially used about things that are free of impurities that might cause disease. 
"The hospital room must be completely SANITARY." 
"Conditions are not very SANITARY around here. We must clean everything thoroughly."

VIGOR.deftext:
power, strength, energy, pep 
VIGOR is strength or energy that comes from good health. 
"He attacked the problem with VIGOR." 
"Her constant VIGOR makes others tired; they wonder how she keeps it up." 
The adjective form of VIGOR is VIGOROUS, which means _strong_ or _forceful_. 
"The VIGOROUS series of exercises left her gasping for breath." 
Other forms of the word: VIGOROUS, adj.

questions.prompt: Can a rowboat make a lot of HEADWAY during a storm?
Does a stamp collector ACCUMULATE stamps?
Do people like to be GOUGED?
Would it be helpful if you could ANTICIPATE what a teacher was going to ask on a test?
Does skipping pages increase a person's COMPREHENSION of a book?
Is a shirt a piece of APPAREL?
Can you always avoid a problem by CONFRONTING it?
Can a person CONGREGATE by himself?
Would fifteen people in a phone booth be an INSTANCE of overcrowding?
Is a wild dog a FELINE?
Could a person get angry during a CONTROVERSY?
Would the FOREMOST students usually get poor grades?
Is a two-legged person a FREAK?
Although they have made some HEADWAY, scientists still have a long way to go in finding a cure for the disease.
He was ACCUMULATED by the police as a suspect in the robbery.
I ANTICIPATE that there will be no problem in getting him to agree.
She found it difficult to COMPREHEND the meaning of the poem.
Among the APPAREL in the laboratory were test tubes and microscopes.
She CONFRONTED for him so that no one knew he had missed work.
A flock of pigeons started to CONGREGATE around the bread crumbs.
We saw many INSTANCES of poverty in the slums.
With FELINE grace she jumped from rock to rock along the shore.
The whole town liked the CONTROVERSIAL plan to build a new police station.
First and FOREMOST we must remember that other people are depending on us.
A coat of paint helped to make the place a little more HABITABLE.
It was a FREAKISH dream: I was sitting in an igloo playing the piano.
The diamond was IMMENSE; it was almost the size of a golf ball.

HEADWAY.deftext:
progress, advance, movement forward 
HEADWAY is usually used in the phrase "to make HEADWAY," which means "to make progress, to move forward," like a ship making its way through the water. 
"We couldn't make any HEADWAY with the strong wind blowing against us." 
"They reported making some HEADWAY in convincing both sides to agree to stop fighting." 
"I hope to make some HEADWAY in my math project this afternoon."

ACCUMULATE.deftext:
to gather, amass, pile up 
To ACCUMULATE is to _heap up_, to increase gradually into a larger quantity. People can ACCUMULATE things, and things can ACCUMULATE. 
"He has ACCUMULATED a large collection of early American paintings." 
"Water ACCUMULATED in the cellar when the drain became blocked." 
ACCUMULATED is frequently used about money. 
"She ACCUMULATED a fortune in the stock market." 
The noun form is ACCUMULATION, which means "things that are piled up," or "the act of piling up." 
"The ACCUMULATION of knowledge is a worthwhile goal." 
"What an ACCUMULATION of junk!" 
Other forms of the word: ACCUMULATION, n.

GOUGE.deftext:
to dig out, force out 
A GOUGE is a tool for digging out grooves or channels in wood. To GOUGE something is to cut it with, or as if with, a GOUGE. The word suggests something done roughly or crudely. 
"The boy GOUGED a hole in the table with his knife." 
"He GOUGED his initials in the tree trunk." 
To GOUGE someone's eye is to poke a thumb or finger into it. In a special sense, GOUGE can mean to _over-charge_ or _swindle_—that is, to force money from a person. 
"He GOUGED an extra twenty dollars from them because he knew they couldn't get anyone else to do the job."

ANTICIPATE.deftext:
to expect, foresee 
To ANTICIPATE something is to expect or foresee that it will happen, or to deal with it in advance. 
"She ANTICIPATED our arrival and fixed up the guest room for us." 
"He ANTICIPATED that we would refuse at first, so he prepared still more arguments to persuade us." 
"He is very unpredictable; you can never ANTICIPATE what he's going to do next." 
Other forms of the word: ANTICIPATION, n.

COMPREHEND.deftext:
to understand, perceive 
To COMPREHEND something is to grasp it mentally, to understand it. The word often suggests a thorough understanding, a complete grasp of an idea or a subject. 
"No one can really COMPREHEND what it means to live forever." 
"We cannot COMPREHEND his refusal to take such a good job." 
"She was able to COMPREHEND written French, but she could never speak it very well." 
The noun form of COMPREHEND is COMPREHENSION, _understanding_. 
"The intricate workings of an automobile are beyond his COMPREHENSION." 
Other forms of the word: COMPREHENSION, n. COMPREHENSIBLE, adj.

APPAREL.deftext:
clothing, dress, attire 
APPAREL is a rather fancy word for a person's clothing. 
"She put on her finest APPAREL for the dance that evening." 
"Everyone laughed at the strange APPAREL he wore to school that day." 
APPAREL is also a verb, meaning to _clothe_ or _dress_. 
"The king was APPARELED in his costliest robes for the ceremony."

CONFRONT.deftext:
to face, encounter 
To CONFRONT something is to have it in _front_ of you, to be or come face to face with it. 
"When we turned the corner a huge wall suddenly CONFRONTED us." 
"They were CONFRONTED with several difficult problems at once." 
Often CONFRONT has the sense of a person facing something defiantly or without flinching. 
"The enemies CONFRONTED each other in the doorway, and neither one would step aside." 
To CONFRONT someone _with_ something is to bring him face to face with it. In this sense CONFRONT often suggests forcing the person to face something he doesn't want to face. 
"They CONFRONTED the prisoner with so much evidence that he was forced to confess." 
Other forms of the word: CONFRONTATION, n.

CONGREGATE.deftext:
to come together, assemble, gather 
See _con-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The _greg_ part of the word comes from the Latin word for a _flock_. To CONGREGATE is to come or bring together in a particular place, to flock together like birds or sheep. 
"The teacher CONGREGATED her students in one corner of the schoolyard." 
"People began to CONGREGATE around the musicians playing on the street corner." 
A CONGREGATION is a gathering or assembly of people, especially people gathering in church to worship together. 
"Everyone in the CONGREGATION rose to sing the hymn." 
Other forms of the word: CONGREGATION, n.

INSTANCE.deftext:
an example, case, illustration 
An INSTANCE is an example or case, especially one given in support of some general statement or truth. 
"She couldn't forgive this latest INSTANCE of disobedience." 
"He brought up many INSTANCES of our being late for school." 
"This is only one INSTANCE of many that I could have mentioned." 
The common phrase "for INSTANCE" means "as an example." 
"He has trouble with math. For INSTANCE, he didn't get any problems right on this test."

FELINE.deftext:
like a cat, pertaining to cats 
FELINE comes from the Latin word for _cat_. The word can mean "of or pertaining to the cat family." Or it can mean "like a cat," having the qualities usually associated with cats, such as gracefulness and quickness. 
"He moved with FELINE grace along the dance floor." 
"She dropped from the ledge with FELINE quickness." 
FELINE can also be used as a noun to mean _cat_ or "a member of the cat family." 
"FELINES are noted for their swiftness."

CONTROVERSY.deftext:
a dispute, argument, debate 
A CONTROVERSY is a disagreement or dispute that can last for a long time and involve many people. The word usually suggests that a more important issue is being discussed than in an argument. 
"The plan to raise taxes created a CONTROVERSY." 
"Great CONTROVERSY surrounded the decision to build a new high school." 
"The two doctors engaged in a long CONTROVERSY over the value of the medicine." 
Something that is CONTROVERSIAL causes CONTROVERSY or debate. 
"The CONTROVERSIAL book suggests that no one should have to go to school." 
Other forms of the word: CONTROVERSIAL, adj.

FOREMOST.deftext:
chief, best, first 
_Fore-_ at the beginning of a word usually means _at the front_, _before_. Something that is FOREMOST is in front of everything else; it is the first in order, importance, value, etc. 
"He is one of the league's FOREMOST pitchers." 
"She is the nation's FOREMOST expert on health care." 
The phrase "first and FOREMOST" means _most important_, "before anything else." 
"First and FOREMOST, let me explain why I have brought you here tonight."

HABITABLE.deftext:
livable, fit to be inhabited 
To _inhabit_ a place is to live in it. A place that is HABITABLE is able to be lived in. See _-able_ under Suffixes. HABITABLE does not suggest that a place is very beautiful or comfortable, only that people can live in it. 
"The house has no plumbing, heat, or electricity; it just isn't HABITABLE." 
"The room isn't fancy, but it is HABITABLE." 
"Tests showed that the planet had an atmosphere like the Earth's; it was probably HABITABLE."

FREAKISH.deftext:
odd, abnormal 
The basic meaning of FREAK is "a sudden change or turn of the mind." From this it has come to be used about a thing or person who is extremely strange or abnormal. 
"The snowstorm in July was really a FREAK. We'll never see another one like it." 
FREAKISH is the adjective from FREAK. See _-ish_ under Suffixes. It means _unusual_, _bizarre_, _extremely strange_. 
"No one could understand his FREAKISH behavior lately." 
"He had a FREAKISH talent for remembering every phone number he ever heard." 
"It was a FREAKISH potato: it was almost the size of a basketball." 
Many people think FREAKISH means _stupid_. Someone who is or appears to be out of the ordinary is not necessarily _stupid_, however. 
Other forms of the word: FREAK, n.

IMMENSE.deftext:
huge, vast, extremely large 
IMMENSE means "so big or great that you can hardly measure it." The word is used about size, numbers, amounts, and so on. 
"The museum was IMMENSE. It would take you weeks to see everything that's in it." 
"There was an IMMENSE crowd on the beach that day." 
"There is an IMMENSE amount of work to be done before we will be finished." 
Other forms of the word: IMMENSITY, n.

questions.prompt: Do people usually like someone who MEDDLES in their affairs?
Are some deaf people also MUTE?
Can you NEGOTIATE with someone you don't like?
Is wearing a seatbelt in a car a PRECAUTION?
Can you RESUME an activity that you haven't done for a long time?
Is a burnt-out light bulb SERVICEABLE?
Can a boat CAPSIZE with people in it?
Can a person COLLABORATE by himself?
Would a person usually be COMMENDED for stealing money?
The river INTERCEPTED the city right down the middle.
I don't like to MEDDLE, but I think you should listen to my advice.
She always has MISGIVINGS after she agrees to do something difficult.
He stood MUTE with wonder before the brilliant painting.
The two lawyers NEGOTIATED a settlement in the case, so it never came to trial.
He received a PRECAUTION from the teacher about his poor behavior.
She was in the habit of telling lies, but she REFORMED when she realized the trouble she caused.
I RESUME that everyone will want to come to the beach with us.
The mechanic didn't make the car as good as new, but at least it was SERVICEABLE.
After several years of living in the busy city, she longed for the TRANQUILITY of life in the country.
He got several ANONYMOUS messages saying he would be killed if he talked to the police.
They used a complicated APPARATUS to help him breathe after the operation.
They managed to hold onto the boat that had CAPSIZED until they were saved.
No one wanted to COLLABORATE with the enemy soldiers when they conquered the city.
The principal COMMENDED them for their fine record in school.

INTERCEPT.deftext:
to cut off, interrupt the course of 
See _inter-_ under Prefixes. 
To INTERCEPT something is to stop or catch it on its way from one place to another. In football, when someone INTERCEPTS a pass, he catches it before it reaches the person for whom it was intended. To INTERCEPT a message is to overhear or see it while it is going from the sender to the receiver. 
"We tried to INTERCEPT the enemy's planes before they reached their targets." 
Other forms of the word: INTERCEPTION, n.

MEDDLE.deftext:
to interfere, butt in 
To MEDDLE is to involve yourself in something without being asked or without having the right. 
"People would get angry with him because he liked to MEDDLE in their private business." 
"Please don't MEDDLE with these papers. They're too important." 
"They accused him of MEDDLING, but he said he had every right to know what was going on." 
Usage: MEDDLE is usually followed by _with_ or _in_.

MISGIVING.deftext:
a doubt, suspicion 
To have MISGIVINGS about something is to feel doubt or suspicion about it, to be unsure that it is right or that it will work. 
"I had MISGIVINGS about this project from the start. I'm not surprised that it has failed completely." 
"My mind was full of MISGIVINGS. I wasn't sure I wanted to do this at all." 
"She had MISGIVINGS about hiring Bob. He didn't look honest to her." 
Usage: MISGIVING is usually used in the plural, MISGIVINGS.

MUTE.deftext:
silent, speechless, unable to speak 
A MUTE is someone who is unable to speak, usually because he was born deaf and has never heard spoken sounds. As an adjective, MUTE means _silent_, _not talking_. A person can be MUTE not only because he can't speak, but because he doesn't choose to speak. 
"He remained MUTE while his mother scolded him." 
"She took the food with MUTE thanks." 
MUTE is also a verb which means "to muffle or soften the sound of." 
"He MUTED the trumpet."

NEGOTIATE.deftext:
to bargain, try to come to an agreement 
NEGOTIATE is especially used in business, law, and diplomacy. It can mean to _carry out_ or _conduct_. 
"She NEGOTIATED an important business deal." 
Usually, though, its meaning is "to arrange for or settle by bargaining or discussion." 
"The union NEGOTIATED a new contract." 
"He NEGOTIATED a peace treaty between the enemies." 
Other forms of the word: NEGOTIATION, n.

PRECAUTION.deftext:
a safeguard; foresight 
See _pre-_ under Prefixes. _Caution_ is _care_, _carefulness_. PRECAUTION is care taken ahead of time in order to avoid something bad happening. 
"He told them to use PRECAUTION when they were sailing in rough seas." 
A PRECAUTION is an act of caution done ahead of time. 
"She took an umbrella as a PRECAUTION in case it rained later." 
"You must take every PRECAUTION before clearing the mine field." 
Other forms of the word: PRECAUTIONARY, adj.

REFORM.deftext:
to correct, improve, change for the better 
REFORM basically means "to form something over again." See _re-_ under Prefixes. Usually REFORM has the sense of changing something for the better by removing faults or evil ways. 
"The business promised to REFORM its sales practices so that it wouldn't mislead people." 
"The kindly teacher managed to REFORM the rough boys by his good example." 
When someone REFORMS,he corrects bad habits and improves his character. 
"I used to be an alcoholic,but I've REFORMED and now I never take a drink." 
A REFORM school or REFORMATORY is a place which tries to REFORM children who have broken the law. 
Other forms of the word: REFORMATION, n. REFORMATORY,n.

RESUME.deftext:
to begin again, start anew 
See _re-_ under Prefixes.To RESUME something is to take it up again after having stopped for a time. 
"After a year of rest she RESUMED working." 
"He came back twenty minutes later and RESUMED the story exactly where he had left off." 
"I RESUMED playing tennis when the doctor said I should get more exercise." 
When something RESUMES it starts over again. 
"The show RESUMED after the commercial." 
Other forms of the word: RESUMPTION,n.

SERVICEABLE.deftext:
useful, helpful, able to be used, fit for use 
SERVICEABLE means "able to be of SERVICE," _useful_. See _-able_ under Suffixes. If you make something SERVICEABLE, you fix it so that it can be used. 
"His shoes were repaired so that they were SERVICEABLE for everyday use." 
SERVICEABLE often suggests that something is good enough for use without being outstanding. A SERVICEABLE object may not be the best or newest, but it will do the job. 
"The pot was dented,but it was SERVICEABLE." 
Other forms of the word: SERVE, v. SERVICE, n.

TRANQUIL.deftext:
peaceful,calm,serene, unruffled 
TRANQUIL means "free from anything that bothers or excites," peaceful. 
"They live in a TRANQUIL little village, far from the noise and rush of the city." 
"He remained TRANQUIL while everyone else ran about in confusion." 
"The TRANQUIL stream became a noisy waterfall when it dropped off the cliff." 
The noun from TRANQUIL is TRANQUILITY,which means _peacefulness_ or _calmness_. 
"The nation's TRANQUILITY was disturbed by rumors of war." 
"The TRANQUILITY of the afternoon was suddenly shattered by peals of thunder." 
Other forms of the word: TRANQUILITY, n. TRANQUILIZER, n.

ANONYMOUS.deftext:
nameless, of unknown name 
ANONYMOUS means "without a name." The word is used about a person whose name is not known or has not been revealed. 
"The person who sent the gift wishes to remain ANONYMOUS." 
"The composer of this ancient song is ANONYMOUS." 
It is also used to mean "of unknown source or origin." 
"He received an ANONYMOUS phone call telling him where the bomb was located." 
ANONYMITY is the state of being ANONYMOUS. 
"The author tried to preserve his ANONYMITY by signing a false name to the article." 
Many people think ANONYMOUS means _mysterious_. An ANONYMOUS person might be mysterious, but for a specific reason: because his name is unknown. 
Other forms ofthe word: ANONYMITY,n.

APPARATUS.deftext:
equipment, mechanism 
An APPARATUS is a set of instruments, materials, appliances, or machinery designed to work together for a specific purpose. In the human body it is a group of organs that work together toward one end. 
"The skindiver's breathing APPARATUS was faulty. The oxygen tank did not connect properly with the nose mask." 
A fire truck is commonly called a fire APPARATUS because of all the various instruments it has that serve in fighting a fire. 
"The building's powerful heating APPARATUS consists of a huge furnace and dozens of ducts that carry hot air circulated by fans."

CAPSIZE.deftext:
to overturn, upset 
CAPSIZE is used especially about boats. The word means "to turn upside down from a safe to a dangerous position." A boat can CAPSIZE, or something can CAPSIZE a boat. 
"The little rowboat CAPSIZED in the rough waters of the bay." 
"A huge wave CAPSIZED the canoe." 
On the Pretest, _sink_ is a common choice as the meaning of CAPSIZE. When a boat CAPSIZES, however, it just turns over in the water. It is in danger of sinking, but it will not necessarily sink.

COLLABORATE.deftext:
to work together, cooperate 
See _con-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. Notice the word _labor_ in the middle of COLLABORATE. To COLLABORATE is to _labor_ or _work together_. 
"Other scientists COLLABORATED with him in carrying out the research." 
The word is often used about works of literature. 
"The two authors COLLABORATED on a novel." 
In a special sense, COLLABORATE often is used to mean "to work with an enemy of one's country." 
"After the war he was accused of COLLABORATING with the enemy forces." 
Other forms of the word: COLLABORATION, n. COLLABORATOR, n.

COMMEND.deftext:
to praise, recommend; to entrust 
To COMMEND someone is to speak favorably of him, to praise him. 
"I COMMEND you for your honesty." 
"Bill's mother COMMENDED his handling of the emergency." 
Often the word suggests praising someone or something to someone else. In this sense COMMEND is close in meaning to _recommend_. 
"The critic COMMENDED the book to anyone interested in fine writing." 
In another sense, COMMEND means to _entrust_ or _commit_. 
"The dying man COMMENDED his soul to God." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _scold_, which is just about the opposite of COMMEND. 
Other forms of the word: COMMENDABLE, adj. COMMENDATION, n.

I couldn't stand the REEK of his cheap cigars.
It's hard to RETAIN your sense of humor when everyone is yelling at you.

REFINE.deftext:
to purify 
To REFINE something is to _purify_ it, to remove other substances from it so that it is pure and unmixed. Products like iron, oil, and sugar are REFINED before they are sold. To REFINE a person is to improve his manners, speech, and so on, to make him more elegant and cultivated. In this sense, the adjective REFINED means _polished_, _cultured_, "free from coarseness or vulgarity." 
"He is a very REFINED gentleman. He is always very polite and attentive." 
Other forms of the word: REFINEMENT, n. REFINERY, n.

INTRICATE.deftext:
complicated, complex, involved 
INTRICATE comes from a Latin word meaning to _entangle_. Something that is INTRICATE has so many parts and connections working together in such complicated ways that it becomes difficult to follow or understand. 
"We marveled at how long it must have taken to weave the INTRICATE pattern in the rug." 
"It was hard to make sense of the INTRICATE plot of the spy novel." 
"This INTRICATE machinery can only be fixed by an expert." 
Other forms of the word: INTRICACY, n.

DENSE.deftext:
thick, compact 
DENSE means "crowded closely together," _thick_. 
"The trees were very DENSE in that part of the forest. It was very difficult to make your way through them." 
"It was impossible to see anyone or anything in the DENSE fog." 
"There was a DENSE crowd around the man playing the guitar." 
The noun from DENSE is DENSITY, _thickness_. 
"There were flowers everywhere, but they were at their greatest DENSITY right in the middle of the garden." 
Other forms of the word: DENSITY, n.

PERTAIN.deftext:
to relate, belong as a part, be connected 
PERTAIN means "to have to do with." PERTAIN does not necessarily suggest a strong or close connection, but would often be used about things that belong properly or fittingly to a particular subject or situation. 
"None of his suggestions PERTAINED to the particular problem they were facing." 
"We understand most of the circumstances that PERTAIN to her illness." 
Usage: PERTAIN is usually followed by _to_.

CORRUPT.deftext:
dishonest, immoral 
To be CORRUPT is to be dishonest, immoral, or bad. The word is often used about public officials who take bribes and sell political favors. 
"The mayor was so CORRUPT that the townspeople had him thrown out of office." 
"Some people are CORRUPT in small ways, but can be very honest about other things." 
CORRUPT is also a verb that means "to make dishonest or impure." 
"They tried unsuccessfully to CORRUPT him. They offered him large bribes to falsify the records, but he refused them." 
Other forms of the word: CORRUPTION, n.

DELINQUENCY.deftext:
negligence, wrongdoing 
To be DELINQUENT is to do wrong, often by failing to do a duty. 
"He was DELINQUENT in paying his taxes." 
DELINQUENCY is the state of being DELINQUENT. It is wrongdoing or neglect of duty. 
"As a result of his DELINQUENCY in making the payments, the bank took the car away from him." 
"Juvenile DELINQUENCY" is wrongdoing by youths. 
"The police could not handle the increase in juvenile DELINQUENCY." 
Other forms of the word: DELINQUENT, adj., n.

ENSEMBLE.deftext:
a group; a general effect 
Note the pronunciation. ENSEMBLE is a French word meaning _together_, and the English pronunciation is almost the same as the French. In English, an ENSEMBLE is a group of people or things that act together to produce some result. The word is used about a group of musicians who play together. It is also used about items of clothing that go together to form a complete outfit. 
"The complete ENSEMBLE costs much less when purchased all at once." 
ENSEMBLE is also used about the general effect of something taken as a whole. 
"Viewed individually the parts of the building were all beautiful, but the ENSEMBLE was somehow unsatisfying."

FRAIL.deftext:
weak, lacking strength, easily broken, fragile 
FRAIL comes from the same Latin word as _fragile_. Both mean _weak_, _easily broken_. FRAIL is most often used about health and physical makeup. 
"Tim is a very FRAIL little boy; he should not be forced to play rough sports." 
"She is in FRAIL health; a sudden shock might do her great harm." 
FRAIL is sometimes used about other things as well. 
"He thought the bridge looked rather FRAIL, so he decided not to drive his truck over it." 
The noun from FRAIL is FRAILTY. 
"As he grew older, his FRAILTY increased." 
"This one little problem showed the FRAILTY of the entire system." 
Many people think FRAIL means _old_. An _old_ person is not necessarily FRAIL, however. 
Other forms of the word: FRAILTY, n.

EXTENSIVE.deftext:
wide, broad, far-reaching, thorough 
To EXTEND means to _stretch out_ or _reach_. 
"This desert EXTENDS for miles in every direction." 
Something which is EXTENSIVE EXTENDS far, has a wide range. See _-ive_ under Suffixes. 
"He owns an EXTENSIVE farm which covers most of the county." 
"She has traveled EXTENSIVELY throughout the world." 
"Jane has an EXTENSIVE knowledge of history." 
"The car needed EXTENSIVE repairs." 
Other forms of the word: EXTEND, v. EXTENSION, n.

GLIMMER.deftext:
a dim, unsteady light; a faint idea, vague indication 
GLIMMER is related to the word _gleam_. Both are kinds of light. A _gleam_ is a flash of light, not very bright and usually not lasting very long. A GLIMMER is an even weaker light, so faint and unsteady that you are just able to see it. 
"He saw the GLIMMER of their flashlights far up on the mountain." 
GLIMMER is also used as a verb. 
"The campfire GLIMMERED in the distance." 
GLIMMER is also used to apply to ideas, hopes, possibilities, and other things that may be very faint. 
"There was only a GLIMMER of hope left that any of them would make it." 
"She didn't show a GLIMMER of the talent she was supposed to have."

INSTANTANEOUS.deftext:
done in an INSTANT, immediate 
An INSTANT is a very short space of time. 
"He will be back in an INSTANT." 
INSTANTANEOUS comes from INSTANT and means "done or happening in an INSTANT." 
"He pulled the switch, and the explosion was INSTANTANEOUS." 
"Their response to his suggestion was almost INSTANTANEOUS. They agreed right away." 
"He never suffered. Death was INSTANTANEOUS." 
_Unexpected_ is often chosen as the meaning of INSTANTANEOUS, probably because you do not always expect something to happen immediately. 
Other forms of the word: INSTANT, n.

NOTABLE.deftext:
worthy of note, remarkable, outstanding, striking 
NOTABLE means "deserving to be noted or noticed," _remarkable_. The word is usually used in a good sense about someone who deserves to be famous because of his excellence. 
"She was NOTABLE for her great skating ability." 
"Many NOTABLE men and women were invited to dine with the president." 
"Putting a man on the moon was a NOTABLE achievement."

PENETRATE.deftext:
to enter into, pass into or through 
To PENETRATE something is to enter or pass into it. 
"They PENETRATED deeper into the cave than anyone had before." 
"The needle just barely PENETRATED the skin." 
"We must PENETRATE into enemy territory before dawn." 
PENETRATE is also used in a general sense about seeing into or understanding something. 
"How far can scientists PENETRATE into the secrets of nature?" 
Other forms of the word: PENETRATION, n.

REEK.deftext:
a strong smell 
A REEK is a strong, usually unpleasant smell. 
"We could smell the REEK of rotting fish." 
"The REEK of garlic was almost overpowering." 
REEK is also a verb meaning "to give off a strong, unpleasant odor." 
"The locker room REEKED with sweat." 
"The closet REEKED of stale perfume." 
Usage: As a verb, REEK is usually followed by _of_ or _with_.

RETAIN.deftext:
to keep, continue to have; to keep in place 
To RETAIN something is to hold onto it, to continue to have it. It is related to other words like _obtain_ and _contain_ which have to do with getting and holding. 
"Despite the other team's rally, we RETAINED the lead at halftime." 
"She RETAINS all the energy and enthusiasm she had when she was much younger." 
RETAIN also means "to keep in place." 
"A dam was built to RETAIN the water." 
"Female kangaroos RETAIN their young in pouches on their abdomens."

questions.prompt: Is an animal that is kept in a cage able to ROVE?
Is a baby COMPETENT to drive a car?
Is a SECLUDED house far away from other houses?
Do athletes SEEK to be champions?
Would a talking horse cause a SENSATION?
Can there be just one person in a CONSPIRACY?
Can people like each other and still SQUABBLE?
Would a person who has no opinions take many STANCES on issues?
Would most people EXERT themselves in running ten miles?
Does a good night's sleep FATIGUE you?
Does a thirsty person find a drink of water GRATIFYING?
We were EXTRACTED from buying a new car by the high price.
Our ROVING days came to an end when we settled down in a small valley.
The guards searched the woods for the FUGITIVE.
I was impressed by his COMPETENCE at typing.
He was constantly going to parties to find SECLUSION.
They were SEEKING a good place to vacation.
He had a strange SENSATION that someone was following him.
They use only the highest quality TEXTILES in making these suits.
We shot the pigeons with a SNARE.
The reporter discovered a CONSPIRACY to hide the truth about the plane crash.
It was just a minor SQUABBLE. No one got very angry.
The president was praised for his STANCE on foreign aid.
Everyone ignored his EXERTIONS to the team to try harder.
Just watching them work so hard almost makes me feel FATIGUED.
He GRATIFIED us that we had to go with him or we would be punished.

EXTRACT.deftext:
to pull out, draw forth, obtain 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes. To EXTRACT something is to pull it out of something else. The word usually suggests that force or effort was necessary. 
"The dentist EXTRACTED the tooth." 
"The doctor EXTRACTED the bullet from his shoulder." 
EXTRACT also often suggests pulling something out against someone's will. 
"Before we left, we EXTRACTED a promise from him that he would behave." 
"After three days of torturing the prisoner they managed to EXTRACT the information from him." 
EXTRACT is also used for the process of obtaining juice or some other substance by squeezing, crushing, or boiling something. 
"They EXTRACTED the oil from the peanuts." 
Other forms of the word: EXTRACTION, n.

ROVING.deftext:
wandering, roaming 
To ROVE is to move about a large area, usually without a specific purpose. ROVING means "moving here and there," _wandering_. 
"A ROVING band of gypsies passed by our town last week." 
"There are ROVING wolves out there in the wilderness." 
Other forms of the word: ROVE, v.

FUGITIVE.deftext:
a runaway, one who flees 
A FUGITIVE is a person who runs away. Usually the word is used about escaped criminals or prisoners, but it can be used about anyone who flees. 
"The FUGITIVES who had escaped from prison last night were last seen headed for the mountains." 
"We captured the FUGITIVE after a long chase." 
FUGITIVE is also an adjective. 
"The FUGITIVE slaves were caught and returned to their masters." 
As an adjective, FUGITIVE often means _fleeting_, _passing quickly_. 
"These FUGITIVE dreams were difficult to recall afterwards." 
_Thief_ is often chosen as the meaning of FUGITIVE on the Pretest. A FUGITIVE may be a criminal or someone who has done something wrong, but he is not necessarily a _thief_.

COMPETENT.deftext:
able, capable, well qualified 
Someone who is COMPETENT can do what is required in a particular job. COMPETENT does not suggest outstanding ability, but ability that is satisfactory or adequate for what has to be done. 
"Ted thinks he's a wonderful drummer, but I think he's just barely COMPETENT." 
"Now that he's fourteen, we think he's COMPETENT to take care of his little sister." 
"She is COMPETENT in math and chemistry, but she has never been any good at languages." 
The noun from COMPETENT is COMPETENCE, which means _ability_ or _skill_. 
"No one would question his COMPETENCE as a teacher. His students really learn the subject." 
COMPETENT is often thought to mean _pleasant_. A person can be COMPETENT, however, without being pleasant at all. 
Other forms of the word: COMPETENCE, n.

SECLUSION.deftext:
privacy, aloneness, isolation 
SECLUSION is the noun form of the verb SECLUDE. To SECLUDE something is to keep it away from others. 
"She led a SECLUDED life far away from the rest of humanity." 
SECLUSION means _privacy_, _isolation_. A person or thing that is in SECLUSION is cut off from others, either willingly or unwillingly. 
"He searched for SECLUSION from the noise and bustle of the city, so he moved to a village in Vermont." 
"We kept the cat in SECLUSION until she had her kittens." 
Other forms of the word: SECLUDE, v.

SEEK.deftext:
to search for, look for, try to find; to try, attempt 
To SEEK something is to look for it, to try to find it. 
"The young man went to London to SEEK a job." 
"She was SEEKING shelter from the wind while she waited for the bus." 
When followed by _to_, SEEK means to _try_ or _attempt_. 
"She SEEKS to become the first person to climb that mountain." 
Many people think SEEK means _find_. But someone who SEEKS something may not _find_ it. 
"He SOUGHT wealth, but remained poor." 
Usage: The past tense of SEEK is SOUGHT.

SENSATION.deftext:
a feeling, awareness; excitement 
To SENSE is to have feeling, to have an awareness of something through your SENSES. 
"The dog SENSED that someone was coming"—that is, it heard, smelled, or saw that someone was coming. 
SENSATION is a noun from SENSE. Its basic meaning is a _feeling_, an _awareness_ of some kind. 
"He felt a slight tickling SENSATION on his skin." 
"It was a wonderful SENSATION to sink into the warm bath." 
SENSATION is also used for a state of excited feelings occurring among a group of people. 
"Her appearance caused quite a SENSATION at the party." 
The word can also stand for a person or thing causing the SENSATION. 
"Her new dress was the SENSATION of the party." 
Other forms of the word: SENSE, v., n. SENSATIONAL, adj.

TEXTILE.deftext:
a cloth, fabric, material 
A TEXTILE is a cloth or some material that can be woven into a cloth. Silk, wool, and cotton are examples of TEXTILES. 
"The TEXTILE for the king's robe has threads of gold in it." 
"Many towns in New England used to have TEXTILE mills." 
"His company specializes in TEXTILES that are used for curtains." 
Many people choose _factory_ as the meaning of TEXTILE, probably because TEXTILES are made in factories.

SNARE.deftext:
a trap 
A SNARE is a trap which is used to catch animals. It is usually made of wire or cord formed into a loop. 
"The trapper set out several SNARES for rabbits." 
The word can also be used in a general sense about anything that traps. 
"They found themselves caught in the SNARES of the sick man's evil plans." 
SNARE is also a verb meaning to _trap_, _entangle_, or _catch_. 
"He was SNARED in the tangles of his lies."

CONSPIRACY.deftext:
a plot, secret plan 
See _con-_ under Prefixes. To CONSPIRE is to plot together secretly, usually to do something illegal. 
"Those men CONSPIRED to steal thousands of dollars from the government." 
A CONSPIRACY is this act of plotting, or the people who do the plotting. 
"There is a CONSPIRACY in the company to cover up their illegal actions." 
"He joined a CONSPIRACY which was out to overthrow the government." 
A "CONSPIRACY of silence" is a secret agreement not to talk publicly about something. 
"There was a CONSPIRACY of silence about the possible dangerous side effects of the new drug." 
Other forms of the word: CONSPIRATOR, n. CONSPIRATORIAL, adj. CONSPIRE, v.

SQUABBLE.deftext:
to quarrel, argue, fight, bicker 
To SQUABBLE is to quarrel or argue about something unimportant. The word does not suggest very bitter or angry feelings. 
"They often SQUABBLE over what to eat for supper." 
"He SQUABBLED with his neighbors over who was supposed to fix the fence." 
SQUABBLE is also a noun and means "a small, unimportant quarrel." 
"They had a SQUABBLE over which TV program to watch." 
Many people think to SQUABBLE means to _make noise_, probably because SQUABBLES are often noisy.

STANCE.deftext:
a position, stand, attitude 
A person's STANCE is his position when standing up. 
"In the painting the king had an unusual STANCE, leaning back against his horse." 
"The golfer took up his STANCE next to the ball and prepared to hit it." 
STANCE can also be used about a mental position or attitude. 
"He never changed his firm STANCE on the uselessness of exercise." 
"Once his father took a STANCE on something, he never changed his mind."

EXERTION.deftext:
effort, vigorous action, exercise, struggle 
To EXERT means to _bring into use_, to _put forth_. 
"He EXERTED all his strength to move the refrigerator." 
"Janet EXERTED her influence to help her friend get a job." 
To EXERT yourself is to put forth effort in doing something. EXERTION is the act of EXERTING. EXERTION is usually difficult and requires a great deal of effort. 
"In spite of all his EXERTIONS he couldn't move the piano." 
"She was worn out from the EXERTION of trying to teach her students." 
Mental EXERTION is effort that uses the mind. 
"His job involved much running around, but little mental EXERTION." 
Other forms of the word: EXERT, v.

FATIGUE.deftext:
to tire, weary, exhaust 
FATIGUE is both a verb and a noun. FATIGUE is _tiredness_, usually caused by working too hard, either physically or mentally. 
"After four hours of digging they were overcome by FATIGUE and had to rest." 
To become FATIGUED is to tire out. 
"Cleaning the house quickly FATIGUED him." 
"They were too FATIGUED to swim any further." 
Many people think that to be FATIGUED is to be _bored_. Sometimes the words may be close in meaning, as in the sentence "His constant talking began to FATIGUE her." But the words do not have the same meaning.

GRATIFY.deftext:
to please, satisfy, indulge 
See _-fy_ under Suffixes. GRATIFY comes from a Latin word meaning _pleasing_, _thankful_, also the source of the words _grateful_ and _gratitude_. Someone who is _grateful_ is pleased about something, is thankful for it. To GRATIFY someone is to make him pleased, to give him pleasure by satisfying his desires. 
"Your decision to go on to college GRATIFIES me tremendously." 
"We are all GRATIFIED with the results." 
"I am GRATIFIED to learn that you are finally earning some money." 
Other forms of the word: GRATIFICATION, n. GRATIFYING, adj.

questions.prompt: Would a blind person have ACUTE vision?
Do TYPHOONS occur at the North Pole?
Can doctors sometimes REVIVE patients whose hearts have stopped beating?
Could a flower be a MEMENTO?
Is the presidency a LOFTY position?
Would a dull TV show be called INCOMPARABLE?
Is getting up in the morning a PHENOMENAL action?
Is the president of the United States INFALLIBLE?
Is reading INSTRUMENTAL in increasing your vocabulary?
Would grass be PARCHED after a blizzard?
Would a RELUCTANT reader be likely to go to the library often?
Was George Washington a TRAITOR to the United States?
Didn't the baby look ACUTE in her pretty pink bonnet!
A warm TYPHOON blew softly in from the sea.
The other team's dirty play REVIVED our determination to win.
Jim wrote himself a MEMENTO about going to the store after school.
He was so ILLITERATE that he wouldn't even lend his own mother a dollar.
Ed had a LOFTY opinion of himself. He thought he was one of the greatest men in the world.
He is an INCOMPARABLE painter; no one is quite as great as he is.
He was a PHENOMENAL athlete. He starred in every sport he tried.
No one has yet found an INFALLIBLE way to cure all diseases.
I hope I can be INSTRUMENTAL in helping you with this project.
He MANEUVERED his way up close to the famous actor.
The huge explosion PARCHED the house.
He is very RELUCTANT; something always goes wrong with things he tries to do.
She THRUST her hand into the hole and felt around for the lost ring.
She was blackmailed into becoming a TRAITOR to her country.

ACUTE.deftext:
sharp, extreme, severe, keen 
ACUTE can be used in several slightly different ways, all with the basic meaning of _sharp_. When the word is used to describe the senses, feelings, or the mind it means _sharp_, _keen_, _quick_. 
"The doctor advised him that an ACUTE pain in his chest could be due to a heart attack." 
"Dogs have an ACUTE sense of smell." 
"We hired the man because of his ACUTE mind." 
A situation can be ACUTE when it is severe, urgent, and demanding of attention. 
"There was an ACUTE shortage of housing after the war." 
"This information is of ACUTE importance." 
An ACUTE triangle in geometry is a sharp angle, one that is less than 90°.

TYPHOON.deftext:
a hurricane, storm 
A TYPHOON is a violent storm or hurricane that occurs in the Pacific Ocean around Southeast Asia. During a TYPHOON there are usually huge waves and high winds. 
"The ship was caught in the TYPHOON, but managed to survive the storm." 
"During the TYPHOON many beach houses were swept away by the angry waters." 
"TYPHOONS usually build up in the late summer."

REVIVE.deftext:
to bring back to life, renew 
To REVIVE is to come or bring back to life. See _re-_ under Prefixes. REVIVE can be used about actual life or consciousness. 
"The doctors managed to REVIVE the patient after his heart attack." 
"She fainted when she heard the news, but quickly REVIVED." 
The word can also be used about things that have become weak, unused, or inactive. 
"Her arrival REVIVED a party that had become dull." 
"They REVIVED a play that hadn't been staged in forty years." 
"My interest in the subject REVIVED when I read this new book." 
Other forms of the word: REVIVAL, n.

MEMENTO.deftext:
a reminder, keepsake, souvenir 
MEMENTO comes from the Latin word for _remember_, also the source of the word _memory_. A MEMENTO is an object that is kept in memory of a certain person or event. 
"She kept the ticket stub as a MEMENTO of their evening together." 
"They presented him with the football as a MEMENTO of the victory." 
"She liked to keep MEMENTOS of all the happy occasions of her life."

ILLITERATE.deftext:
uneducated, unable to read or write 
The word _literate_ comes from the Latin word for _letter_. A _literate_ person is educated; specifically, he knows the alphabet, he knows how to read and write. 
"He was barely _literate_. It took him a long time to read just one sentence." 
The opposite of _literate_ is ILLITERATE. See _in-2_ under Prefixes and _-ate2_ under Suffixes. ILLITERATE means "unable to read and write." 
"He was totally ILLITERATE. He had no idea what a book was for." 
"How many students are ILLITERATE when they graduate from high school?" 
Other forms of the word: ILLITERACY, n.

LOFTY.deftext:
high, towering; elevated, noble, stately 
An old meaning of the word _loft_ was the _upper regions_, the _sky_. This meaning is still found in the word _aloft_, which means _in the air_. LOFTY is also related to _loft_ and means _very high_, _towering_. See _-y_ under Suffixes. 
"We were all impressed by the LOFTY mountains." 
"The eagle was in its LOFTY nest." 
LOFTY always includes a sense of dignity and impressiveness. The word is often used about ideas, people, speeches, and so on. 
"He expressed his LOFTY thoughts in equally noble language." 
"She achieved her LOFTY position through hard work and talent."

INCOMPARABLE.deftext:
beyond compare, unequaled, matchless 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes and _-able_ under Suffixes. To _compare_ things is to judge how much alike they are. INCOMPARABLE means "not able to be compared with anything else." INCOMPARABLE is almost always used about good qualities. Something that is INCOMPARABLE is so wonderful or great that nothing else even comes close. 
"Her cookies were good, her pies were delicious, but her cakes were INCOMPARABLE." 
"His ability to add numbers in his head was INCOMPARABLE." 
"Her INCOMPARABLE charm made us all like her."

PHENOMENAL.deftext:
extraordinary, outstanding, remarkable 
The basic meaning of the noun PHENOMENON is "an observable fact or event," but in common use, PHENOMENON is generally applied to _extraordinary_ facts, events, or people. 
"This young basketball player is a PHENOMENON. He scores forty points every game." 
PHENOMENAL is the adjective from PHENOMENON. See _-al_ under Suffixes. Something that is PHENOMENAL is very surprising or extraordinary. 
"He had PHENOMENAL success in the stock market." 
"She made a PHENOMENAL recovery and came home only three days after the operation." 
"A PHENOMENAL number of people voted in the last election; an all-time record was set." 
Other forms of the word: PHENOMENON, n.

INFALLIBLE.deftext:
not capable of making a mistake, unfailing, unerring 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes. Someone who is _fallible_ is capable of error. 
"You'll have to excuse his occasional mistakes. He's only _fallible_, after all." 
Someone who is INFALLIBLE is never wrong, cannot make a mistake. 
"He has an INFALLIBLE eye for talent." 
"She is INFALLIBLE at predicting the winners of football games." 
Something that is INFALLIBLE never fails; it is certain to succeed. 
"He had an INFALLIBLE cure for hiccups." 
"He claimed he had discovered an INFALLIBLE method for getting rich quick." 
Other forms of the word: INFALLIBILITY, n.

INSTRUMENTAL.deftext:
useful, helpful 
The basic meaning of the noun INSTRUMENT is "a means by which something is done." A surgical INSTRUMENT is a tool that is useful in performing surgery. A musical INSTRUMENT is an object with which you make music. 
INSTRUMENTAL means "serving as an INSTRUMENT or means." See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"His suggestion was INSTRUMENTAL in solving the problem; without it I don't know what I would have done." 
"His spectacular fielding was INSTRUMENTAL to our victory." 
Other forms of the word: INSTRUMENT, n. 
Usage: INSTRUMENTAL is often followed by _in_ or _to_.

MANEUVER.deftext:
a planned movement of troops; a skillful move 
The basic meaning of MANEUVER is "a military or naval movement," carried out with regard to the position of the enemy, the condition of the land, and so on. 
"The general carried out a skillful MANEUVER which brought our troops around to the rear of the enemy." 
From this the word has come to be used about any skillful move or plan designed to win something, do something, or escape from something. 
"He used a clever MANEUVER to get them both in the same room together." 
"The newspaper criticized the tricky MANEUVERS he had used to win the election." 
MANEUVER is also a verb. 
"She MANEUVERED her way through the crowd." 
"He MANEUVERED them into agreeing with his position."

PARCHED.deftext:
dry, dried out, scorched 
To PARCH something is to dry it out, especially through too much heat. 
"Three straight months of sunlight PARCHED the corn." 
Something that is PARCHED is dried out. 
"Nothing will grow in this PARCHED land. It's almost a desert." 
"After running a mile in the heat his throat was PARCHED. He longed for a drink of water." 
Other forms of the word: PARCH, v.

RELUCTANT.deftext:
unwilling, disinclined 
Someone who is RELUCTANT to do something doesn't want to do it. He may do it, but it would be done against his will. 
"I was RELUCTANT to enter the haunted house." 
"June was RELUCTANT to go to the party at first, but we talked her into it." 
"Bill convinced his RELUCTANT father to let him have the car." 
Many people think RELUCTANT means _eager_, which is an exact opposite. 
Other forms of the word: RELUCTANCE, n.

THRUST.deftext:
to push, shove 
To THRUST something is to push or shove it forward with great force or suddenness. 
"She THRUST the money at the cab driver and didn't wait for change." 
"The soldier THRUST his sword into the man's side." 
"He THRUST his hands into his pockets to keep them warm." 
THRUST is also a noun which means a _push_ or _shove_. 
"The army's THRUST into enemy territory was pushed back." 
On the Pretest, the most common wrong answer for the meaning of THRUST is _pull_, which is an exact opposite. 
Usage: The past tense of THRUST is the same as the present tense: THRUST.

TRAITOR.deftext:
a betrayer 
A TRAITOR is a person who is not loyal to his own country or side. A TRAITOR betrays the people who trust him. 
"Benedict Arnold was a TRAITOR to the United States when he gave secrets to the British." 
"He is the worst kind of TRAITOR, because he betrayed his friends for money." 
Many people confuse TRAITOR with _spy_. A spy is a person who tries to obtain secret information. He may work for his own country or for someone else's, so a spy is not necessarily a TRAITOR. 
Other forms of the word: TRAITOROUS, adj.
