When something is ALTERED, it is always better?
If a person spends two hours trying to open a stuck window, is he being PERSISTENT?
Would DOMESTIC cigars have to be brought into the country?
Could a PATHETIC sight make a person cry?
Can something get in through a door that is AJAR?
Can something new have any AUTHENTICITY?
Would a CHAMBERMAID be a maid who cleans bedrooms?
Do people who are in love like to EMBRACE?
Do most JUVENILES go to school?
If a football team won by sixty points, did it win HANDILY?
This new lock is FOOLHARDY; I guarantee it will never fail.
We shouldn't ALTER the arrangement of furniture in the room.
Long ago scientists disproved the popular CONCEPT that Earth was the center of the universe.
If you PERSIST in making noise you won't get any dessert tonight.
Although he was always getting into trouble at work, his DOMESTIC life was calm and peaceful.
The boy started crying PATHETICALLY when he realized he was lost.
We locked the doors and made sure they were completely AJAR.
He wanted to get a darker blue, so he used a different PIGMENT.
They put steel rods into the pole to keep it RIGID.
We tried to be AUTHENTIC about his mistake, but we were just too upset by it.
Their FRANK admiration of his work made him feel good.
They held their meetings in a large CHAMBER on the second floor.
They EMBRACED her by telling her everything was going to be all right.
Although my father is almost fifty, he's still pretty JUVENILE in some ways.
The lamp fell off the shelf and broke HANDILY on the floor.

FOOLHARDY.deftext:
reckless, foolishly brave 
One meaning of the word _hardy_ is _brave_, _daring_. 
"The _hardy_ adventurers set off to explore the jungle." 
FOOLHARDY means _foolishly hardy_. Someone who is FOOLHARDY takes unnecessary risks and lacks judgment in facing danger. 
"They were FOOLHARDY to try to swim across the flooding river." 
"The FOOLHARDY boy tried to walk a tightrope between the two buildings." 
Many people think FOOLHARDY means _brave_. But in FOOLHARDY the emphasis is on being _foolishly_ brave. 
"He thought he was brave to attack the enemy headquarters singlehandedly, but everyone else thought he was FOOLHARDY."

ALTER.deftext:
to change 
To ALTER something is to make it different without changing it completely. 
"We ALTERED the schedule to allow the principal to speak first." 
"The book made him ALTER his ideas on many subjects." 
"The house looked greatly ALTERED as a result of the redecorating." 
Other forms of the word: ALTERATION, n.

CONCEPT.deftext:
an idea, thought, notion 
CONCEPT is related to the word CONCEIVE, which means to _think_ or _imagine_. 
"I cannot CONCEIVE of a better way to spend the day." 
A CONCEPT is an _idea_, especially a general idea. 
"The CONCEPT of gravity is not an easy one to understand." 
"He agreed with the CONCEPT that all men are created equal." 
"The teacher tried to teach him the CONCEPT of fractions." 
Other forms of the word: CONCEPTION, n. CONCEPTUAL, adj.

PERSISTENT.deftext:
continuing, lasting, enduring 
PERSIST means to _keep on_ or _continue_. 
"The rain will PERSIST through the weekend." 
When someone PERSISTS in doing something, he keeps on doing it despite opposition. 
"He PERSISTED in trying to open the door even after we told him it was nailed shut." 
Someone or something that is PERSISTENT is inclined to PERSIST. See _-ant_ under Suffixes. 
"He is a very PERSISTENT salesman. He just won't take no for an answer." 
"She's had that PERSISTENT cough for over a week now. I think she should see a doctor." 
"The reporter's PERSISTENT questions finally uncovered the truth." 
"The PERSISTENT increase in prices has everyone worried." 
Other forms of the word: PERSIST, v. PERSISTENCE, n.

DOMESTIC.deftext:
of the home or family; native 
DOMESTIC comes from the Latin word for _house_. DOMESTIC means "of the home, family, or house." 
"The man's DOMESTIC problems interfered with his work." 
"When he became rich he hired a butler, a maid, and other DOMESTIC help." 
"He never achieved DOMESTIC happiness; he was divorced three times." 
In a broader sense, DOMESTIC can mean "of one's own country" and is the opposite of _foreign_ or _imported_. 
"He said that some DOMESTIC wines are as good as the best imported French wines." 
"The president's DOMESTIC policy stressed lower taxes and less crime." 
Other forms of the word: DOMESTICATE, v. DOMESTICITY, n.

PATHETIC.deftext:
pitiful, pitiable, sad, sorrowful 
Something that is PATHETIC stirs up the emotions of pity and sympathy in people. 
"The housing inspector told the reporter that the living conditions in the slum were PATHETIC." 
"A PATHETIC little dog was roaming around our neighborhood last night, crying for its owner." 
"The actress who had been so proud and beautiful in her youth was now old and PATHETIC." 
Sometimes PATHETIC stresses how bad or inadequate something is. In this sense, something that is PATHETIC stirs up contempt more than pity. 
"Our basketball team's performance was just PATHETIC last night. We lost by fifty points." 
Other forms of the word: PATHOS, n.

AJAR.deftext:
partially open 
AJAR means _slightly open_. AJAR is used about anything that can be opened and closed, but it is used mainly about doors. 
"She left the door AJAR so that a little light came in." 
"The burglar found a window that was AJAR, so he climbed in through it."

PIGMENT.deftext:
coloring, coloring matter 
PIGMENT is the part of paint or other material that gives it its color. 
"The artist mixed several PIGMENTS together to get the color he wanted." 
"Many PIGMENTS are made of natural materials." 
Other forms of the word: PIGMENTATION, n.

RIGID.deftext:
stiff, unbending; strict, inflexible 
Something that is RIGID is hard to bend; it is stiff and unyielding. 
"These poles must be RIGID or the tent will collapse." 
"His back had to be kept RIGID after the operation." 
This meaning is extended to apply to anyone or anything that is strict, firm, or hard to change. 
"They had a RIGID system for teaching arithmetic in that school. Teachers had to follow it exactly." 
"All the rules are RIGIDLY enforced, so you had better not break any." 
"Why do you have to be so RIGID about this? Couldn't you give in just a little?" 
Other forms of the word: RIGIDITY, n.

AUTHENTIC.deftext:
real, genuine, true 
Something that is AUTHENTIC is what it is said to be; it is not faked. 
"If that painting is AUTHENTIC, then it's worth many times what you paid for it." 
"The difference between an AUTHENTIC diamond and a fake one isn't always easy to see." 
"This dog is an AUTHENTIC champion; he has won many awards." 
The noun form of AUTHENTIC is AUTHENTICITY, which means _genuineness_. 
"I cannot accept the AUTHENTICITY of this coin until I have it examined by an expert." 
AUTHENTIC is often confused with _old_. Something that is brand new can be AUTHENTIC, however, if it is genuine or true. 
Other forms of the word: AUTHENTICITY, n.

FRANK.deftext:
open, sincere, outspoken, candid, undisguised 
Someone who is FRANK speaks openly about what is on his mind; he doesn't hide or disguise his opinions or feelings out of shyness or politeness. 
"He was very FRANK in his opinion of my intelligence: he told me I was a total moron." 
FRANK can also be used about the opinions or statements of someone who is FRANK. 
"He made a FRANK confession about why he had really come." 
"Her FRANK criticism was exactly what I needed." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest is _good_, probably because FRANKNESS is usually thought to be a good quality.

CHAMBER.deftext:
a room; an enclosed space 
A CHAMBER is a _room_, particularly a private room or a bedroom in a house. 
"The judge has a special CHAMBER next to the courtroom where he can have private discussions with people." 
"The queen went to her private CHAMBER up near the top of the castle." 
CHAMBER is also used about any kind of small enclosed space. A part of a gun is a small CHAMBER that holds the bullet to be fired. 
Usage: CHAMBER is a rather formal word, and would not often be used in everyday speech.

EMBRACE.deftext:
to hug, to make use of, come to believe in 
To EMBRACE a person is to take him or her into your arms, usually to show your friendship or love. EMBRACE can be either a verb or a noun. 
"We EMBRACED eagerly." 
"They held each other in a long EMBRACE." 
EMBRACE is also used in a wider sense, meaning "to take or accept eagerly," as if it were a loved one you were EMBRACING. To EMBRACE an opportunity is to welcome it and make use of it immediately. To EMBRACE a cause is to believe wholeheartedly in it. 
"Many scientists immediately EMBRACED the new theory."

JUVENILE.deftext:
a young person, a youth 
A JUVENILE is a young person. 
"As a JUVENILE, he had to work every bit as hard as he did when he grew up." 
"The three JUVENILES were sent home and told to obey their parents." 
As an adjective, JUVENILE is often used in a bad sense to mean _immature_, _childish_. 
"We thought his silly practical jokes were rather JUVENILE." 
Many people pick _criminal_ as the meaning of JUVENILE. This is probably because JUVENILE is often used in the phrase "JUVENILE delinquent." A "JUVENILE delinquent" is a young person who breaks the law and cannot be controlled by his or her parents. Only a few JUVENILES are "JUVENILE delinquents," however.

HANDILY.deftext:
easily, expertly 
HANDILY comes from the word HANDY. Someone who is HANDY is clever in using his hands. 
"He is very HANDY at fixing things around the house." 
HANDILY means "with little trouble," _easily_. It is used about anything that happens or is done with no difficulty, not just things that require using your hands. 
"In spite of falling down at the beginning of the race, he came back to win HANDILY." 
"She passed her final exams HANDILY." 
Other forms of the word: HANDY, adj.

questions.prompt: Does one hundred EXCEED one thousand?
Would a book of famous sayings be a COMPILATION?
Are people usually MASSACRED in hospitals?
Does a LAVISH person save all his money?
If two statements CONTRADICT each other, can they both be true?
Can you OBTAIN knowledge by reading books?
Do people who are in a hurry like to LINGER?
Do people like to be AMUSED?
Is CONCEIT usually considered a bad quality?
Does Russia still have a CZAR?
Should a tightrope walker keep his EQUILIBRIUM?
Do GRIM men laugh a lot?
She finally EXCEEDED in getting the car to start.
The lawyer COMPILED a great deal of evidence that showed the defendant was innocent.
Thousands of people were MASSACRED by the fierce invaders.
He LAVISHED so many treats on the puppy that it soon became quite fat.
Bob CONTRADICTED me and said it really wasn't true.
Once she had the beautiful painting, she OBTAINED it all her life.
Some of these superstitions LINGERED on despite the scientific evidence against them.
She UTTERED him to wipe his feet before he came into the kitchen.
The teacher showed no sign of AMUSEMENT at the students' practical joke.
He tried to be a CASUALTY but people could tell he was really quite excited.
Sarah tried to be CONCEITED and let other people take all the glory.
The water flowed rapidly through the long GULLY.
In the old days, one CZAR would rule the entire industry; now it is so big several people have to run things.
The angrier he got, the more his EQUILIBRIUM increased.
He takes a GRIM delight in tormenting the younger children.

EXCEED.deftext:
to go beyond, be greater than, outdo 
To EXCEED means to _go beyond_. The word is used in various senses of _going beyond_: _going beyond_ what is necessary, for example, or what is allowed, or what someone else has done. 
"The driver EXCEEDED the speed limit by going ninety miles an hour." 
"The captain EXCEEDED the general's orders when he told his men to attack immediately." 
"Her swimming ability EXCEEDED everyone else's." 
"The price of the car EXCEEDS what we want to pay for it." 
Other forms of the word: EXCESS, n. EXCESSIVE, adj.

COMPILE.deftext:
to collect, assemble, gather together 
To COMPILE is to _collect_. The word is especially applied to collecting information or items of any kind and arranging this material into a book, report, chart, or the like. 
"They COMPILED a list of voters who might favor their candidate." 
"We COMPILED a chart of average salaries using figures we received from the government." 
The word can also mean to _gather together_ or _pile up_. 
"He COMPILED all the figures necessary for the report." 
"The candidate COMPILED a huge number of votes in the election." 
A COMPILATION is something (like a book or list) that has been put together from other sources. 
"This book is a COMPILATION of the best sports stories of the year." 
Other forms of the word: COMPILATION, n.

MASSACRE.deftext:
a general slaughter, mass killing 
A MASSACRE is the cruel killing of a large number of people. The word is especially used about the killing of people who are not able to defend themselves. 
"The soldiers shot the people in cold blood, but everyone was too scared to talk about the MASSACRE." 
MASSACRE is also a verb, meaning "to kill in a MASSACRE," to _slaughter_. 
"The enemy MASSACRED all the women and children in town." 
MASSACRE is often confused with _battle_. Both may involve fighting and killing, but they do not have the same meaning.

LAVISH.deftext:
unlimited, profuse, extravagant, overly generous 
LAVISH comes from an old French word meaning "a downpour of rain." To be LAVISH is to give or produce something abundantly, to pour it forth like raindrops. The word often has the sense that too much is being given or produced. LAVISH is used about the person giving something or about the thing being given. 
"He was LAVISH in his praise of her singing." 
"He wrote some LAVISH praise of her singing." 
"When he struck it rich, he became a LAVISH spender. He wanted to buy everything." 
LAVISH is also a verb. 
"He LAVISHED praise on the new novel."

CONTRADICT.deftext:
to deny, dispute 
CONTRADICT comes from Latin words which mean to _speak against_. To CONTRADICT something is to say or show that it is untrue. 
"We CONTRADICTED his statement that the Earth is flat." 
"Bill had evidence that CONTRADICTED my theory." 
You can also CONTRADICT a person. 
"The girl CONTRADICTED him when he said that New York City was the capital of New York." 
CONTRADICT can also mean "to be the opposite of, be contrary to." 
"Your two statements CONTRADICT each other. Which is true?" 
Other forms of the word: CONTRADICTION, n. CONTRADICTORY, adj.

OBTAIN.deftext:
to get, gain possession of 
To OBTAIN something is to _get_ it. OBTAIN often suggests more effort or planning or a longer wait than _get_. 
"I managed to OBTAIN two tickets for the game Saturday night." 
"Jane finally OBTAINED a new pair of skis." 
"He OBTAINED the right book from another library." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _keep_. This may be due to confusion with the word _retain_, which means to _keep_ or _hold on to_. OBTAIN has to do only with _getting_ something, not _keeping_ it.

LINGER.deftext:
to stay, remain, delay; to continue to exist 
To LINGER is to stay in a place longer than usual or expected. 
"We LINGERED on the beach long after everyone else had gone home." 
"I LINGERED for a long time over that one beautiful painting before passing on to the next one." 
LINGER also means "to continue to exist although becoming weaker." 
"After his heart attack, he LINGERED for only a few days before dying." 
"A few very old customs still LINGER on among the natives." 
Usage: LINGER is sometimes followed by _on_.

UTTER.deftext:
to speak, say 
UTTER basically means "to make a sound with the mouth." 
"She UTTERED a little cry of disappointment." 
From this, UTTER is usually used to mean _speak_ or _say words_. 
"Bobby had reached the stage when it seemed that the only word he could UTTER was _no_." 
"The last word he UTTERED was 'Goodbye.'" 
The noun form of UTTER is UTTERANCE, which means _something spoken_. 
"She thought his every UTTERANCE was extremely funny." 
In the Pretest item, _make up_ is the most common incorrect choice. The word UTTER involves only speaking and making sounds, however, not thinking or planning. 
Other forms of the word: UTTERANCE, n.

AMUSEMENT.deftext:
fun, entertainment 
To AMUSE someone is to make the time pass pleasantly for him, especially by making him laugh. 
"We AMUSED ourselves by looking at old photographs." 
"The comedian AMUSED everyone in the audience." 
AMUSEMENT is the state of being AMUSED. See _-ment_ under Suffixes. 
"The kitten's playful actions gave everyone a great deal of AMUSEMENT." 
An AMUSEMENT is also something that AMUSES a person. 
"There are plenty of AMUSEMENTS for little children at the fair." 
Many people choose _excitement_ as the meaning of AMUSEMENT. Something that AMUSES you does not have to be exciting, though. 
Other forms of the word: AMUSE,v.

CASUALTY.deftext:
an accident; a victim 
A CASUALTY is an accident in which someone is injured or killed. 
"The heavy storm caused several traffic CASUALTIES." 
The person who is killed or injured is also called a CASUALTY. 
"Seven CASUALTIES resulted from the explosion." 
The word is often used about injured or killed soldiers. 
"Each side suffered hundreds of CASUALTIES during the battle."

CONCEITED.deftext:
vain, proud, egotistical 
CONCEIT is an overly high opinion of yourself, a feeling that you are superior to everyone else. 
"His incredible CONCEIT caused him to believe that he was the greatest living writer." 
Someone who is CONCEITED is full of CONCEIT. 
"Jan was so CONCEITED she wouldn't speak to any of us. She said we weren't good enough for her." 
"Her CONCEITED brother thinks he is the handsomest fellow in the world." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _humble_, which is the exact opposite of CONCEITED. 
Other forms of the word: CONCEIT, n.

GULLY.deftext:
a ditch, channel 
A GULLY is a ditch or channel, formed by running water, which serves as a natural drain for rainwater. 
"Several GULLIES in the side of the hill overflowed during the heavy rains." 
Many people choose _stream_ as the meaning of GULLY. A GULLY might have been formed by a stream, but it is really the channel in which water is carried, not the water itself.

CZAR.deftext:
a ruler, emperor 
Note the pronunciation; the _c_ is silent. CZAR is a Russian word which came originally from the name _Caesar_. The CZAR was the ruler of Russia in the days before the Russian Revolution of 1917. 
"CZAR Ivan the Terrible was a cruel ruler of Russia during the sixteenth century." 
CZAR has also come to be used about anyone who has absolute power and authority. 
"The police said that this man was the CZAR of organized crime in this part of the country." 
"The movie CZAR decided that his studio should also make television shows." 
Usage: CZAR is also sometimes spelled _tsar_.

EQUILIBRIUM.deftext:
balance 
EQUILIBRIUM comes from Latin words meaning _equal balance_. EQUILIBRIUM is the state of being balanced, especially when the balance is due to the equal action of opposing forces. The word is often used in science, but it is also in general use. 
"He lost his EQUILIBRIUM as he walked along the top of the fence, and he tumbled to the ground." 
The word is often used with regard to a person's emotional balance. 
"She had difficulty recovering her EQUILIBRIUM after someone in the audience yelled an insult at her." 
EQUILIBRIUM is also used about balances in society. 
"The EQUILIBRIUM of the social order was destroyed when the population of one of the two major groups in the country increased dramatically in a short period of time."

GRIM.deftext:
harsh, severe, stern, forbidding; ghastly 
GRIM means _stern_, _severe_. The word is used about the way people look. 
"The GRIM expression on his face told us he was quite angry." 
It is also used about conditions or actions that are harsh or unpleasant. 
"Neither fighter could stand up at the end of the GRIM struggle." 
"It was his GRIM task to count the dead bodies." 
The phrase "GRIM necessity" applies to something that is unpleasant but has to be done. 
"GRIM necessity forced us to drink the dirty water." 
Sometimes GRIM has an even stronger sense of _ghastly_, _horrifying_. 
"It was a GRIM tale of murder and torture."

questions.prompt: Do people often RESIDE in factories?
Can countries make PACTS with one another?
Do you like something that makes you RECOIL?
Is it possible to INFLICT damage on a car if you hit it with a hammer?
Does an INTENTION have to do with the future?
Do parents have an OBLIGATION to care for their children?
Can you PORTRAY a person in a story?
Is a jet STATIONARY when it is in the air?
Would a brand new building have been RENOVATED?
Would most people want to go to a doctor who has a SKETCHY knowledge of medicine?
Would it be difficult to TOPPLE a mountain?
Do most people YEARN for happiness?
At work he was mild and kind, but at home he was an unjust TYRANT to his children.
After living in a cottage all summer, he returned to his permanent RESIDENCE.
Mona Lisa was IMMORTALIZED in Leonardo Da Vinci's painting.
The heavy PACT was almost impossible to carry.
He RECOILED at the thought of eating raw oysters.
I have never been so INFLICTED in my life as when I heard that we had won the lottery.
I INTEND to go to Europe some day, no matter how much it costs.
I have no OBLIGATION to help you do your homework.
The actor PORTRAYED a character who loved money more than anything else.
We bolted the wobbly table to the wall so that it would remain STATIONARY.
The landlord called in a wrecking crew to RENOVATE the building.
Her SKETCHY voice was very unpleasant to listen to.
The ice cream was TOPPLED with a chocolate sauce.
Mrs. Jones YEARNED to see her children.
She bought new curtains to brighten up the DRAB room.

TYRANT.deftext:
a dictator, cruel ruler 
A TYRANT is a person who seizes power in a country and then proceeds to rule in a very cruel and unfair way. A TYRANT is a _dictator_, a person whose word is law. 
"The TYRANT grew wealthy by placing taxes on just about everything." 
"The people hated the TYRANT who ruled over them in such a cruel fashion." 
The word TYRANT is also used about any person who rules others unfairly. 
"He thinks his mother is a TYRANT just because she won't let him drive at night." 
Other forms of the word: TYRANNICAL, adj. TYRANNIZE, v. TYRANNY, n.

RESIDE.deftext:
to live, dwell 
To RESIDE in a place is to live there, to have your home there. 
"He RESIDES in Florida now." 
"She RESIDES in one state, but works in another." 
A RESIDENCE is a place where someone lives, a _home_, especially a large or dignified one. 
"Their RESIDENCE is the brick house at the end of the street." 
It is also the act of RESIDING. 
"After years of living in a house we took up RESIDENCE in an apartment." 
Other forms of the word: RESIDENCE, n. RESIDENTIAL, adj.

IMMORTAL.deftext:
undying, deathless, lasting forever 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes and _-al_ under Suffixes. The Latin word __mors means death. It is the source of the words _mortal_ and _mortality_. Someone or something that is IMMORTAL will not die, will last forever. The word is usually applied to people's souls or to their actions and achievements. 
"Patrick Henry said those IMMORTAL words, 'Give me liberty or give me death!'" 
"Everyone should read Shakespeare's IMMORTAL plays." 
To IMMORTALIZE something is to make it last or be remembered forever. 
"Longfellow's poem IMMORTALIZED Paul Revere's ride." 
Other forms of the word: IMMORTALITY, n. IMMORTALIZE, v.

PACT.deftext:
an agreement, compact 
A PACT is an agreement between persons or groups. 
"We made a PACT that neither of us would tell the secret." 
PACT is often used when referring to agreements or treaties between countries. 
"The two nations signed a PACT that each would help the other in time of war." 
"The PACT limited the size of each nation's army."

RECOIL.deftext:
to draw back, move backward, shrink 
See _re-_ under Prefixes. To RECOIL is to draw back or jump back, especially because of fear, horror, or disgust. 
"I RECOILED when he offered to let me hold the spider." 
RECOIL does not always suggest an actual physical movement. You can RECOIL inwardly from something as well. 
"They RECOILED in horror from the idea of visiting the haunted house." 
RECOIL is also used with regard to a gun kicking back when it is fired. 
"He steadied himself so that he wouldn't be knocked over when the rifle RECOILED."

INFLICT.deftext:
to lay on, impose 
To INFLICT something is to cause it to be suffered. You always INFLICT something unpleasant or painful, like damage or physical punishment. 
"The bomb INFLICTED serious damage on the city." 
"The bully INFLICTED a terrible beating on him." 
Other forms of the word: INFLICTION, n. 
Usage: INFLICT is usually used with _on_: to INFLICT something on someone.

INTENTION.deftext:
purpose, aim 
INTEND means "to have in mind as something to be done." 
"I INTEND to go to the beach this summer." 
An INTENTION is something that you have in mind that you want to do, a _purpose_ or _goal_. 
"I have no INTENTION of watching television tonight." 
"His INTENTIONS were good, but he didn't carry them out." 
"She announced her INTENTION to run for mayor in the next election." 
Many people think an INTENTION is a _wish_. The words are close in meaning, but INTENTION suggests a much stronger determination to do something. Anyone can wish to be famous, for example; but if it is your INTENTION, you are going to work hard to see that it happens. 
Other forms of the word: INTEND, v. INTENTIONAL, adj.

OBLIGATION.deftext:
a duty, responsibility 
An OBLIGATION is something that you must do (or not do). It is a duty that results from a law, a custom, a promise, or the like. 
"He felt he had an OBLIGATION to help those less fortunate than he was." 
"You have an OBLIGATION to pay back the money I lent you." 
"He carried out his OBLIGATION to the company, and then felt he didn't have to do anything more." 
"There is no OBLIGATION to buy anything. We just want you to try our product for ten days." 
Other forms of the word: OBLIGE, v.

PORTRAY.deftext:
to picture, describe, represent 
To PORTRAY means "to make a picture of" someone or something. You can PORTRAY by painting. 
"He PORTRAYED the queen as a beautiful young woman in the painting." 
Or you can PORTRAY in words. 
"The king is PORTRAYED as a villain in this novel." 
Actors PORTRAY characters on stage; that is, they present a picture of the characters. 
"She PORTRAYED Hamlet's mother in the play." 
A PORTRAIT is a picture, particularly a painting of a person. 
"Whistler painted a famous PORTRAIT of his mother." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest item is _deceive_, probably because of confusion with _betray_. 
Other forms of the word: PORTRAIT, n.

STATIONARY.deftext:
unmoving, fixed in position 
STATIONARY is related to the word STATION. Both come from a Latin word meaning to _stand_. One meaning of STATION is "a place where something or someone stands." 
"A guard should never leave his STATION." 
Something that is STATIONARY stands in one place; it cannot or does not move. 
"Nothing was moving on the whole street. All the cars were STATIONARY." 
"These heavy machines are STATIONARY; once they are set in place they can't be moved."

RENOVATE.deftext:
to restore, renew, revive 
See _re-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The _nov_ part of the word comes from the Latin word for _new_, also the source of the words _novel_ and _novelty_. To RENOVATE something is to make it new again. The word is usually applied to the restoring and repairing of old buildings so that they are like new again. 
"We would like to RENOVATE our apartment. We want to fix it up completely." 
"The kitchen was old-fashioned and had to be RENOVATED before they could sell the house." 
Many people think RENOVATE means _tear down_, which means just about the opposite. 
Other forms of the word: RENOVATION, n.

SKETCHY.deftext:
incomplete, like a SKETCH, without details 
A SKETCH is an outline of something, a quick drawing, not the complete picture. Anything that is SKETCHY is like a SKETCH. It is incomplete, lacking in detail. See _-y_ under Suffixes. The word is used especially about understanding or information that is only vague and incomplete. 
"Her understanding of algebra is somewhat SKETCHY." 
"He could only give us SKETCHY directions on how to get there." 
"We had only a SKETCHY idea of what the movie was supposed to be about." 
Other forms of the word: SKETCH, n., v.

TOPPLE.deftext:
to fall, fall over; to push over, overturn 
To TOPPLE is to _fall over_, especially from being too heavy on top. 
"He piled the bricks so high that the stack TOPPLED." 
"The strong winds finally caused the tree to TOPPLE with a crash." 
To TOPPLE something is to push it over or overturn it. 
"The mean boys TOPPLED the snowman we had just finished." 
The word is often used about the overthrowing of someone in a position of authority. 
"The rebels TOPPLED the dictator's government."

YEARN.deftext:
to long, pine 
To YEARN for something is to desire it strongly, usually with an eager or tender kind of feeling. 
"He YEARNED for one last chance to see his native land." 
"Billy YEARNED to be a famous baseball player." 
"The prisoner YEARNED to be free." 
YEARNING is the noun from YEARN. A YEARNING is a longing or a strong desire. 
"She felt a deep YEARNING to help humanity." 
"He never satisfied his YEARNING for more money." 
Other forms of the word: YEARNING, n.

DRAB.deftext:
dull, monotonous, uninteresting, colorless 
Something that is DRAB is uninteresting, colorless, lifeless. 
"His wife's lovely personality lent color to his otherwise DRAB existence." 
The word DRAB is also used in a more specific sense to describe a dull, muddy brown or gray color. 
"The DRAB color scheme of the room made it lifeless and uninviting." 
Many people think DRAB means _filthy_. Something may be colorless and dull, however, and still be perfectly clean.

questions.prompt: Is the smell of roses REVOLTING?
Is it easy to remove someone who is ENTRENCHED?
Would you hire a worker who liked to be IDLE?
Is a student's performance in school EVALUATED when he receives a grade?
Is a good worker NEGLIGENT about his job?
Is a football game usually SERENE?
Has the POTENTIAL winner of a race already won it?
Would a blade of grass OBSTRUCT a highway?
Do most people dislike being SCOLDED?
Are the words of a liar SINCERE?
Are people ever CONFINED as a punishment?
Could a person be old when he makes a DEBUT?
Everyone was REVOLTED by the brutality of the crime.
Walter tried to change their minds, but their views were too firmly ENTRENCHED.
The typewriter is always being used; it is never IDLE.
A new hospital will be ERECTED here next year.
The cost of buying a house is EVALUATING every day.
We accused him of NEGLIGENCE in not making sure his dog was tied up.
They were all so SERENE to me that I burst into tears.
Your idea for a business has POTENTIAL, but you will have to work hard if you want it to succeed.
We tried to OBSTRUCT them about the best way to reach the park.
A year after her operation she seemed to be in RADIANT good health.
My mother SCOLDED me for not doing my homework.
She sent them a gift to show her SINCERE appreciation for their help.
This VICIOUS criminal should be put in prison before he harms anyone else.
They were both CONFINED a hundred dollars for the offense.
The DEBUT of the new singer was postponed for a night.

REVOLTING.deftext:
disgusting, shocking, offensive 
The verb to REVOLT has two meanings: to _rebel_—to REVOLT against the government—and to _disgust_. 
"The sight of all that garbage REVOLTS me." 
REVOLTING comes from this second use and means _disgusting_, _offensive_. 
"I thought the language in that play was REVOLTING." 
"Their REVOLTING behavior makes me sick." 
Other forms of the word: REVOLT, v.

ENTRENCH.deftext:
to place inside a trench, surround with a trench; to establish solidly, fix firmly 
A _trench_ is a long narrow ditch, with the earth from the ditch usually piled up in front of it to serve as protection against an enemy. To be ENTRENCHED is to be surrounded with trenches so that it is very difficult for anyone to attack or overrun you. 
"The army ENTRENCHED itself near the town, and the enemy could do nothing about it." 
From this military use, ENTRENCH has come to mean to _establish firmly_ in any kind of situation. 
"With the passage of time, he became more firmly ENTRENCHED in his position." 
The image is always of someone digging in to become strongly or solidly established.

IDLE.deftext:
unused, unemployed, useless; lazy 
IDLE has several meanings, all of which have the idea "without any purpose or use." IDLE thoughts are useless thoughts, ones that have no particular reason or purpose. An IDLE machine is not being used. 
"During the strike all the factories were IDLE." 
An IDLE person isn't doing anything. 
"We worked hard during the week, but on the weekends we were IDLE." 
IDLE is often used about a person who doesn't _want_ to do anything, who is lazy and avoids work. 
"He is an IDLE sort of boy. He never wants to do anything."

ERECT.deftext:
to set up, raise upright, build, construct 
To ERECT is to set in an upright position. Someone who stands ERECT is standing up straight, without leaning forward or backward. To ERECT something is to put it in this ERECT position. 
"He ERECTED the flagpole." 
ERECT means about the same as _build_, except that it usually adds this sense of raising something upright. 
"They spent six months building the foundation, and then they ERECTED the ninety-story tower." 
Things other than buildings can be ERECTED. 
"They ERECTED legal barriers against foreigners entering the country."

EVALUATE.deftext:
to rate, estimate, appraise 
To EVALUATE something is to judge its value. 
"They EVALUATED the program at the end of the year and decided that it wasn't worth the expense." 
"The critic EVALUATES several new books in this article." 
"It is difficult to EVALUATE the effect this will have on us." 
On the Pretest, many people choose _improve_ as a synonym for EVALUATE, probably because the word looks like _value_ and _valuable_. To EVALUATE is to _judge_ something's value, however, not to _improve_ its value. 
Other forms of the word: EVALUATION, n.

NEGLIGENT.deftext:
careless, neglectful 
NEGLIGENT is one of the adjective forms of NEGLECT. To be NEGLIGENT is to be careless; a NEGLIGENT person doesn't pay attention to or do what he is supposed to. 
"Tom is NEGLIGENT about the way he dresses; he always looks as though he dressed in the dark." 
"The NEGLIGENT waiter forgot to bring the dessert." 
NEGLIGENCE is the noun form of NEGLIGENT. 
"The accident was due to the other driver's NEGLIGENCE. He forgot to look both ways before pulling out into the street." 
Other forms of the word: NEGLECT, v. NEGLIGENCE, n.

SERENE.deftext:
peaceful, calm, tranquil 
SERENE means _peaceful_ and _calm_. The word often has a noble and dignified sense to it. Someone who is SERENE is above the troubles and cares of the world. 
"While everyone else was angry and upset she remained SERENE." 
"They were SERENELY happy for the first year of their marriage." 
"We hoped that the weather would be SERENE on the day of our picnic." 
The noun from SERENE is SERENITY, meaning _calmness_, _peacefulness_. 
"Nothing disturbed the SERENITY of their life together." 
Other forms of the word: SERENITY,n.

POTENTIAL.deftext:
possible 
POTENTIAL comes from the Latin word for _power_. Something that is POTENTIAL has the power to exist or develop. 
"This is a POTENTIAL problem. It isn't a problem now, but it may be one in the future." 
"This boy is a great football player. He is a POTENTIAL All-American." 
POTENTIAL is also a noun. 
"She has the POTENTIAL to become an opera singer"—that is, she isn't one now, but she has the talent to become one. 
POTENTIAL is often confused with _powerful_. The word _potent_ means _powerful_, and the similarity between _potent_ and POTENTIAL probably causes the confusion.

OBSTRUCT.deftext:
to block, hinder, get in the way of 
To OBSTRUCT something is to get in the way of it or to block it up. 
"A pile of rocks OBSTRUCTED the road." 
"The brick wall OBSTRUCTED our progress." 
To OBSTRUCT a person's view of something is to cut it off from his or her sight. 
"The new building OBSTRUCTED our view of the river." 
An OBSTRUCTION is something that blocks or gets in the way. 
"We must remove all OBSTRUCTIONS from our path." 
Other forms of the word: OBSTRUCTION,n.

RADIANT.deftext:
shining, bright, glowing 
To RADIATE is to send out light, heat, or other kinds of rays. Something that is RADIANT is bright and glowing; it looks as if it were sending out rays of light. See _-ant_ under Suffixes. 
"Her RADIANT smile lights up the room." 
"They all admired the RADIANT beauty of the statue." 
"The children's faces were RADIANT with happiness when they saw their father." 
Many people pick _cheerful_ as the meaning of RADIANT. RADIANT is often used to describe people who are feeling positive emotions like joy or love, but it means _bright_ or _shining_, not _cheerful_. 
Other forms of the word: RADIANCE, n. RADIATE, v.

SCOLD.deftext:
to find fault with, reproach 
To SCOLD someone is to find fault with him, usually noisily or angrily. The word suggests an angry or upset parent yelling at a disobedient child. 
"She SCOLDED him for walking across the clean floor in his dirty boots." 
"The teacher SCOLDED us for not paying attention." 
SCOLD is sometimes used as a noun. A SCOLD is someone who is always finding fault. 
"That woman is just a SCOLD. You can't do anything without her yelling at you."

SINCERE.deftext:
honest, not pretended 
SINCERE means _honest_, _open_, _straightforward_. The word is used about people and the way they act. 
"Were you SINCERE when you said you loved me?" 
"He looked at his father with SINCERE admiration." 
"She spoke SINCERELY of her desire to end the strike." 
The noun from SINCERE is SINCERITY. 
"No one doubted his SINCERITY. He honestly believed he was right." 
Many people think SINCERE means _polite_. Sometimes, however, people who are _polite_ are not SINCERE. They say things they don't mean just to be friendly. 
Other forms of the word: SINCERITY, n.

VICIOUS.deftext:
cruel, evil, spiteful, immoral 
VICIOUS is related to the word _vice_, which means _evil_ or an _evil habit_. 
"His only _vice_ is that he gambles too much." 
VICIOUS means "practicing or showing _vice_," particularly violent or cruel vices. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. 
"He is a VICIOUS murderer. He would kill anyone to make a few dollars." 
"She aimed a VICIOUS kick at the dog, but fortunately she missed." 
"He made some VICIOUS remarks about the man's honesty." 
The most common mistakes for VICIOUS are _strong_ and _angry_. A VICIOUS person may be strong and angry, but neither _strong_ nor _angry_ suggests the evil and cruelty that are part of VICIOUS.

CONFINE.deftext:
to limit, enclose, restrain 
To CONFINE something is to keep it within limits. 
"Please CONFINE your remarks to the subject we are discussing." 
"His interests were CONFINED to the area of foreign policy." 
In a related sense, the word often means "to keep shut up" in a particular place, often because of illness, punishment, or the like. 
"The judge CONFINED him to prison for ten years." 
"She was CONFINED to her bed all week with her cold." 
The noun from CONFINE is CONFINEMENT. 
"He couldn't stand CONFINEMENT. He liked to be outside, free to do what he pleased." 
Other forms of the word: CONFINEMENT, n.

DEBUT.deftext:
first appearance, beginning, introduction 
Note the pronunciation. DEBUT is a French word, and keeps its French pronunciation. A person's DEBUT is his or her first public appearance—on stage, in society, in a job, etc. 
"He made his DEBUT as an actor in a small part in Hamlet." 
"Dick's DEBUT as a teacher was terrifying for him. For the first time he had to face a class alone." 
Other forms of the word: DEBUTANTE, n.
